73932.description_html: As a member of the Poultry Club at Virginia Tech, you will learn about a wide variety of topics, ranging from production to research. The club participates in many unique activities, fundraisers and community service projects. These include guest speakers at meetings, industry tours, a fall turkey harvest, National Agriculture Day, a spring egg hunt, the Poultry Federation Youth Convention in Harrisonburg, and a multi-day trip to the International Production and Processing Exposition in Atlanta. Examples of past guest speakers include Mountaire Farms, Sanderson Farms and Cargill. Besides many professional opportunities, members enjoy some fun social events, such as football tailgates with industry professionals and meals with the club. Many members are able to intern at poultry companies and upon graduation, have many career options within the poultry industry.

137157.name: Powerlifting Club at Virginia Tech
137157.summary: A student-based club that focuses on gathering the active powerlifting community
137157.description_html:
Our goal is to teach and supply both inexperienced and experienced powerlifters the proper program and techniques to become a successful as possible. We compete as a team multiple times per year, including on a national level. We are a non gender exclusive club that welcomes all people, in all stages of progression.

 

Make sure to follow our Instagram @vt.powerlifting

69039.name: Pre-Optometry Club at Virginia Tech
69039.summary: This club is for those interested in the field of Optometry. We will focus on information about the field in general, the process of applying to schools, and OAT preparation.
69039.description_html: The Pre-Optometry Club at Virginia Tech is for those who are interested in or may be interested in Optometry. During our meetings, we will go over information regarding the scope of practice, the Optometry Admissions Test (OAT), and how to apply to Optometry school. In addition, speakers from different schools will give members an inside look into their campus and academic program.

68918.name: Pre-Pharmacy Club at Virginia Tech
68918.summary: Our club is dedicated to helping those interested in pharmacy explore the many options available to them. Emphasis is placed on presentations from pharmacy school representatives. We volunteer & participate in community service.
68918.description_html:
The Pre-Pharmacy Club at Virginia Tech is a welcoming community for students exploring careers in pharmacy, whether through the PharmD pathway or the pharmaceutical sciences. Our goal is to provide valuable resources, connections, and experiences that help members navigate their journey toward pharmacy school and beyond.

Each year, we host informative sessions with top pharmacy schools, including recent visits from VCU and UNC, where students gain insight into PharmD programs, prerequisite courses, admissions processes, and life as a pharmacy student. We also explore opportunities in pharmaceutical sciences and drug research, offering guidance for those interested in industry and academic careers.

Beyond academics, the club fosters networking and mentorship, connecting students with pharmacy school representatives, fellow pre-pharmacy peers, and other pre-professional organizations. We are also committed to giving back to the community through volunteer initiatives that support the Blacksburg area.

Whether you are just starting to explore pharmacy or actively preparing for applications, the Pre-Pharmacy Club is here to support you every step of the way. Join us to build connections, gain knowledge, and take meaningful steps toward your future in pharmacy!

72578.name: Pre-Physician Assistant Club
72578.summary: Pre-Physician Assistant Club is geared toward providing a supportive environment to Virginia Tech students who are interested in pursuing a career as a physician assistant. Our semester schedule is posted to our Instagram!
72578.description_html:
Pre-Physician Assistant Club is an organization in which students with the same desired career path may come together to learn more about the courses required for PA school, the admissions process, and PA programs in the nearby area. It is a great club to stay connected with other students interested in pursuing the PA profession as well as PA school representatives.

 

Advisor: Nicolin Girmes-Grieco - ngirmes@vt.edu

President: Isabel Barrett - isabelb23@vt.edu

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/prepavt/

72823.name: Pre-Veterinary Medical Association
72823.summary: Our organization aims to expose prospective veterinary students to the field of veterinary medicine and other animal-related careers. We host events and volunteer closely with organizations that benefit animal welfare to give back to our community.
72823.description_html: Our organization aims to bring pre-veterinary students together through animal husbandry, professional networking, and community outreach. We strive to prepare our members for careers in veterinary medicine while building lasting relationships with peers. To accomplish this, we utilize our close relationship with the Virginia-Maryland College of Veterinary Medicine and the American Pre-Veterinary Medical Association. Common activities include clinical skills labs, service drives for local shelters, and visits to local farms. We typically meet biweekly on Tuesdays in room 100 at the Virginia-Maryland College of Veterinary Medicine with additional activities on a weekly basis. Meetings often consist of lectures from veterinary professionals, veterinary school admissions personnel, and club bonding activities. If you love animals, giving back to your community, and building a foundation for your future career, please come out and join us!

408585.name: PRESENT!! at Virginia Tech
408585.summary: A low-pressure student-led club organization designed to help students embrace their creativity and build up their confidence/public-speaking skills through fun, lighthearted presentations.
408585.description_html:
Looking to advance your public speaking abilities without the pressure of grades or formalities? Look no further!

.

PRESENT!! is a student-led club organization dedicated to fostering a laidback, judgement-free environment for students who are looking to practice presenting in front of a live audience.

.

At the beginning of a given week, members are provided with a fun theme and tasked with creating a slideshow presentation centered around it to present during the following club meeting. These themes can range from "Favorite Topics from My Major" to "Bucket List Items" to "What You'd Change About VT.

.

We encourage members to get as creative as they'd like and showcase what inspires/interests them with few hard limitations. Through this, we hope to assist members in building confidence and skills that will transfer over to more practical situations.

.

Join Our Discord Server For Updates!

65097.name: Pride Council of Virginia Tech
65097.summary: The mission of the Pride Council is to serve the queer and trans communities at Virginia Tech. It act as an umbrella organization over the branching gender, sexual, and romantic-minority serving student organizations.
65097.description_html:
The mission of the Pride Council is to serve the queer and trans communities within Virginia Tech. It shall act as an umbrella organization over the branching gender, sexual, and romantic-minority serving student organizations. It shall strive to enhance belonging of the individual, cultural, and racial diversities that exist in the Queer and Transgender communities through inclusive programming and advocacy. It shall make efforts to address the problems and concerns of the Queer and Transgender communities to the administration and other fellow student organizations.

 

Constituent Organizations

 

Delta Lambda Phi

Fluid: Professional Growth for LGBTQ+ Students

Lavender House Living Learning Program

Queer and Trans People of Color

Queer Grads, Professionals, and Allies

spAAce

 

True Colors

356357.name: Pride Student Veterinary Medical Community at Virginia-Maryland College of Veterinary Medicine
356357.summary: The goal of our PrideSVMC chapter is to advocate for the LGBTQ+ students within VMCVM and to provide them with a safe space where they can be their authentic selves, as well as being a resource to learn more about LGBTQ+ issues and/or identities.
356357.description_html: PrideSVMC at VA-MD College of Veterinary Medicine is a student chapter of national Pride Student Veterinary Medical Community. Our goal is to advocate for LGBTQ+ students with the vet school and to provide them with a safe space where they can be their authentic selves, as well as being a resource to learn more about LGBTQ+ issues and/or identities. We also would like to be a pathway for undergrad students to learn more about the vet school and to witness that there is a community here for them!

387513.name: Primeros Pasos
387513.summary: The mission of Primeros Pasos is to provide Galax High School guidance to pursue higher education and career opportunities after high school through the mentorship of Virginia Tech students from underrepresented minority communities.
387513.description_html: Primeros Pasos is a partnership with Galax High School and Virginia Tech's Center of Rural Education (CRE) & Center of Refugee, Migrant, and Displacement (CRMD). Galax City has the fifth highest percentage of English learners in Virginia. Located in a very rural part of the state near the North Carolina border, the schools have far fewer resources and opportunities than highly populated locations in NOVA. Students who have immigrated or are children of immigrants from Central America may face obstacles to further their education and have limited career opportunities exposure in their community. Thus, Virginia Tech's CRE & CRMD started the Galax Project in the Fall Semester of 2023 which searched for Latinx Virginia Tech students and Spanish speaking Virginia Tech students to serve as mentors and inspirational role models to a cohort of Galax High School students. Our goal is to provide mentorship to prevent dropout and equip the Galax High School students with the resources and tools needed in their chapter upon graduation.

68548.name: PRISM
68548.summary: Pamplin Re-Inventing Social Media: Virginia Tech's College of Business program building relationships between students, faculty, and alumni by enhancing Pamplin's brand via social media.
68548.description_html: PRISM is an interdisciplinary ad agency, run by the next generation of creatives, strategists, analysts and marketing mavens. As student advertisers, we have a deep understanding of the ever-changing digital landscape and have a close eye on the latest trends. We’re constantly looking for what’s next, allowing us to develop innovative, forward-thinking solutions for our clients. With a love for ideation and an insatiable appetite to learn from industry mentors and our faculty advisor, PRISMites are constantly working to push ourselves, and the brands we build, to the next level.

349658.name: Pritchard Hall
349658.summary: Residents and Friends of Pritchard Hall

344664.name: Project Linus at Virginia Tech
344664.summary: Project Linus at Virginia Tech is a non-profit organization focused on creating homemade blankets for children in need with the local NRV chapter. We make blankets from fleece/yarn but no crafting skills are required to join; everyone is welcome.
344664.description_html: Project Linus at Virginia Tech is a sister branch to the NRV chapter of Project Linus and the larger nonprofit organization Project Linus. Our main mission is to create homemade blankets whether that be through knitting, crocheting, quilting, or making simple fleece blankets. All blankets the branch makes are donated to the NRV chapter who will redistribute them to local hospitals and family. We make blankets for children of ages 0-18 and meet once a month as a club to work on blankets but students are free to work on blankets outside of the club as well.

290983.name: Property Management Major
290983.summary: Our degree offers career opportunities in luxury and affordable apartment developments, senior living communities, mixed-use, and office and retail properties. Graduates are equipped with skills that address the complexities of managing real estate.
290983.description_html:
What You'll Study

  • 120 credit hours for a bachelor of science degree, including Virginia Tech's Pathways or Curriculum for Liberal Education (CLE)
  • 32 credits of residential property management courses, including:
    • Multifamily Property Management and Operations
    • Managing and Leasing Commercial Properties
    • Contemporary Issues in Property Management
  • 25-27 credits of approved electives, selected from a variety of disciplines, including:
    • Communication
    • English
    • Finance
    • Human Development
    • Marketing
    • Urban Affairs and Planning
  • 24 credits of AHRM core degree requirements

69089.name: Psi Chi and Psychology Club
69089.summary: The purpose is to provide information about the various fields of psychology, help students prepare for graduate school, inform students about possible job/volunteer opportunities, and host speakers from different psychology areas at meetings.
69089.description_html: Our purpose is to provide information about the various fields of psychology, help students prepare for graduate school, inform students about possible job/volunteer opportunities, and host speakers from different psychology areas at meetings. The organization strives to be a place for all Hokies to feel welcome and share a mutual passion for the field. Visit our Instagram page for more constant updates on the club! @psychclubatvt

79391.name: Psi Gamma Chapter of Theta Tau
79391.description_html:
Our purpose is to develop and maintain a high standard of professional interest among our members, and to unite them in a strong bond of fraternal fellowship.

For more information about our fraternity, please visit us at:

http://www.thetatau.org.vt.edu

114480.name: Public Health Association at Virginia Tech
114480.summary: GPHA is a campus-wide professional, academic, & social organization for graduate & undergraduate students interested in Public Health. We are within the Population Health Sciences Department at the VA-MD College of Veterinary Medicine.
114480.description_html: The Graduate Public Health Association (GPHA) at Virginia Tech is open to any student who is interested in learning more about public health within our communities at Virginia Tech, the NRV, and beyond. We provide educational and professional opportunities to learn more about public health through service, outreach, and workshops. Founded on the "One Health" concept, we consider the relationships between the health of animals, humans, and the environment to promote and improve public health locally, nationally, and globally. GPHA provides opportunities to students to learn more about public health and become active ambassadors on campus and in the community. We generally meet twice a month and host various service, social, and professional skill-building events throughout the semester. There is an annual membership fee and all members receive a t-shirt as well as access to all of the events we sponsor each semester. Any student is welcome regardless of major/minor or program.

69694.name: Public Relations Student Society of America
69694.summary: PRSSA aspires to advance the public relations profession by developing ethically responsible pre-professionals who champion diversity, strive for outstanding education, and advocate for the profession.
69694.description_html: Founded in 1967, the Public Relations Student Society of America (PRSSA) is the foremost organization for students interested in public relations and communications. PRSSA is made up of nearly 7,000 students and advisers organized into 300 plus Chapters in the United States, Argentina, Colombia and Peru. PRSSA can help you gain the experience and practical knowledge employers are seeking. We offer internship listings, competitions, scholarships, awards and leadership opportunities. In addition, PRSSA provides publications, news and social media to keep you updated on industry trends. PRSSA can connect you to a network of peers and professionals who will become lifelong friends and mentors.

181652.name: Quality of Life Plus (QL+) Student Chapter at Virginia Tech
181652.summary: Quality of Life+ offers a unique opportunity to gain leadership experience while serving our local community. All majors and years welcomed.
181652.description_html:
A multi-disciplinary student association on a result-oriented mission to solve distinct problems using engineering processes to improve the quality of life of community members and those who have served through life-changing innovation in prostheses, medical devices and assistive technologies.

Each member gets an opportunity to know the challengers in the community, work on the design and fabrication of the projects, learn new skills through organized workshops, as well as get to know fellow Hokies who share a desire to serve others.

Partnership with QL+: https://qlplus.org/associations/virginia-tech

88023.name: Queer and Trans People of Color at Virginia Tech
88023.summary: QTPOC at Virginia Tech gives faculty, staff, and students the opportunity to understand and celebrate the diversity of being a person of color within the LGBTQ+ community.
88023.description_html:
Who Are We?

Founded by 2 queer black womxn who, in the spirit of Ut Prosim, saw the need and made a space for the minorities of a minority, QTPOC@VT gives faculty, staff, and students the opportunity to gather, understand, and celebrate the diversity of being a person of color within the LGBTQ+ community. Through cultural arts, health, discussion, and advocacy programming we highlight the nuanced experiences of young racial and sexual/gender minorities.

 

Mission Statement

We envision a campus community that is fully inclusive of queer and trans people of color and is committed to dismantling racism, (cis)sexism, heteronormativity, and all other forms of oppression at interpersonal, societal, and institutional levels.

 

What is "Queer"?

Queer is a term used by individuals who do not adhere to what society considers to be "normal" in terms of gender and/or sexuality. Although the term has been used historically by non-LGBTQ people as a derogatory slur, its use by a member of the LGBTQ community is an active reclamation of power from our oppressors; this word that they have used to hurt us cannot hurt us anymore.

68677.name: Queer Grads, Professionals and Allies
68677.summary: QGPA provides LGBT-friendly services, events, and activities for the graduate and professional community of Blacksburg.
68677.description_html:
Join us for community and fun with the queerest grad group on campus! 

We welcome all queer graduate students, professionals, and allies to attend and encourage you to share your input and suggestions for future events and initiatives. 

For more information or to join the QGPA GroupMe and listserv, please contact William Hernández at whernandez@vt.edu or Isaac Riddle at isaacriddle@vt.edu.

414668.name: Radiation Oncology & Oncology Interest Group
414668.summary: The Radiation Oncology and Oncology Interest Group connects interested VTCSOM students with oncology specialists within the Carillon network allowing students to learn more about Radiation Oncology as well as Medical Oncology and Hematology.
414668.description_html: The Radiation Oncology and Oncology Interest Group connects interested VTCSOM students with oncology specialists within the Carillon network allowing students to learn more about Radiation Oncology as well as Medical Oncology and Hematology.

414669.name: Radiology Special Interest Group
414669.summary: The interest group promotes radiology education, mentorship, and career exploration for medical students.
414669.description_html: The interest group aims to introduce medical students to the field of radiology by providing educational opportunities, mentorship, and career exploration. Our mission is to foster interest, promote learning, and support students pursuing radiology.

408587.name: Rainbows at Virginia Tech!!!
408587.summary: Queer space for everyone! Allies welcomed!!!
408587.description_html:
We are a student-led Queer org! Everyone, and I really do mean everyone; queer or not, Blacksburg area or not, are welcomed! <333

We host collaborative events with Queer and Queer adjacent organizations in hopes of achieving a genuine sense of community!

Come join our Discord Server!!! All of our events are posted there!!!

391624.name: Reach
391624.summary: Reach LLC is a community dedicated to engaging students who are pursuing, or contemplating, a major that seeks to serve others through careers in education or human services.
391624.description_html: Individuals who choose these careers directly affect the lives of others and are personally and professionally changed for the better through that service.Reach is an interdisciplinary community of learners, who share the common purpose of dedicating their life in service to others. Everything about the Reach LLC is tailored toward finding how the characteristics that make you, uniquely you, can be applied to serving others and helping them to improve their lives. As students move forward in their studies and anticipate the beginning of their careers in education or human services fields, we believe that deliberate attention to issues that help each of us understand our own strengths, motivations, passions, and more, will result in a more meaningful educational experience while at Virginia Tech, and a deeper sense of purpose and vitality in the work they do moving forward. That is where the power of this community is so evident.

115315.name: Real Estate Club
115315.summary: The Real Estate Club works to allow members to have the opportunity to expand their knowledge, develop valuable relationships, and gain hands-on experience in the dynamic world of real estate.
115315.description_html:
The Real Estate Club at Virginia Tech serves as a catalyst for success in the dynamic realm of real estate, providing a platform for networking, education, and collaboration. With a comprehensive range of real estate resources, exclusive networking opportunities, and a supportive network of like-minded individuals, the Real Estate Club empowers members to achieve their real estate goals and make a lasting impact in their future real estate endeavors.

 

If interested in joining the organization submit this form: https://forms.gle/9aTudSWjitZU3DCo8

 

For any additional questions, please email vtrec1920@gmail.com 

Officers:

Allie Richards - Co-president

Amelia O'Kieffe - Co-president 

Owen Dunn - Operations Chair 

Avery Marable - Marketing Chair 

Samara Ruano - Sophomore Chair 

James Vohs - Freshman Chair

294065.name: Real Greek Life
294065.summary: Real Greek Life at Virginia Tech encompasses the Hellenic culture by hosting events featuring Greek food, music, dancing, fellowship, and service. This club is accepting of ALL students to create long lasting friendships and memories!
294065.description_html: Real Greek Life at Virginia Tech is a window into the Greek lifestyle. Ours goal is to promote Hellenism in the Virginia Tech community, and we encourage both Greek and non-Greek students to participate in all the clubs events. We will focus on Greek Culture which encompasses Greek food, music, dancing, the Eastern Orthodox Religion, fellowship, and service opportunities at Tech and in the local areas. We are hoping that this organization will create a community that aims to spread and teach Greek culture while also creating long-lasting friendships and memories for everyone involved.

114152.name: Rec Sports Leadership Program
114152.summary: This organization is dedicated to enhancing and energizing strong student leadership in rec sports. We are committed to promoting wellness, student development and community for Virginia Tech.
114152.description_html:
The department of recreational sports has established the Recreational Sports Leadership Program for its student supervisor staff.  The program strives to encourage strong leadership in the field of collegiate recreation and student affairs. This year-long program is designed to prepare students with tools and connections they need to succeed in the dynamic field they have chosen to pursue. Students who attend at least 5 of the options will receive the "Recreational Sports Leadership Program" Certificate of Completion.

Program Events:

Fall Semester

Bud to Boss: Supervisor Training

DISC: A tool to help improve teamwork, communication, and productivity in the workplace

Crucial Conversations: Framework for handling conflict.

Spring semester

Basics of Campus Recreation Management: Overview of strategic planning for a campus rec department

Basics of Marketing Strategies

Passing the Torch

139356.name: Recycling Outreach Organization
139356.summary: An organization of students passionate about helping Virginia Tech and its students become more knowledgeable and engaged in campus wide recycling efforts.

68859.name: Red Cross Club
68859.summary: The Red Cross Club at Virginia Tech serves the New River and Roanoke Valley communities with outreach such as blood drives, fire canvassing, disaster relief, preparedness training, and fundraising.
68859.description_html: The Red Cross Club at Virginia Tech serves the New River and Roanoke Valley communities by participating in a variety of training and service outreach. We sponsor on-campus blood drives, assist with local fire canvassing and smoke detector installations, we train to aid in disaster relief, visit local veterans, collect item donations for charitable works, such as Comfort Kits for disaster victims, fundraise, and so much more! This club is a wonderful opportunity to gain volunteer hours and work with other Hokies who share a passion for community service.

68682.name: Reformed University Fellowship
68682.summary: RUF exists to reach students for Christ and equip them to serve. RUF is open to the convinced and the unconvinced - a safe place to ask questions and discover the need for new life in Christ.
68682.description_html:
The purpose of RUF at Virginia Tech is to build a community on campus that reaches students of divergent beliefs and doubts with the message of the gospel and equips them to love and serve Jesus and his church. As we shape our lives around the gospel, we have the opportunity to participate in God's work of changing lives, healing our world, building community, and renewing our culture.

 

- Come join us at our weekly large group on Tuesdays at 8:30 in War Memorial Chapel (snacks provided)! We also host small groups, participate in on-campus recreational sports, and provide rides to church!

- We also participate in HUGE events like Summer Conference, a week-long RUF-wide conference in Panama City Beach, Florida filled with Biblical seminars and hours of free time and fun events (like tug of war and beach volleyball) to spend at the beach or exploring! Of course, Hokie Hoedown, too: a night full of square dancing, local Appalachian music, and great homemade eats! These are just a few (and my favorite) of the many events that we host.

414670.name: Refugee & Immigrant Medical Association
414670.summary: We aims to address the disparities identified in the refugee/immigrant population of Roanoke by offering longitudinal educational guidance as well as providing resources for the children and their families to promote a healthier lifestyle in their home.
414670.description_html: We aim to address the disparities identified in the refugee and immigrant population of Roanoke through a variety of volunteer programs and outreach opportunities. These include tutoring, teaching ESL classes, supporting families in medical appointment coordination, providing free medical exams and health education, collecting needed hygiene and school supplies, raising money for local immigrant and refugee organizations, and advocating for immigrant-friendly local policies.

96170.name: Reiki Club
96170.summary: The Reiki Club at Virginia Tech provides an environment in which students, faculty, and members of the surrounding community can gather to learn and practice the Japanese energy healing art of Reiki.
96170.description_html:
The Reiki Club at VT formed in 2003 and has weekly meetings. Students, faculty, staff, visitors, members of the community and all others interested are welcome to attend for some part or for all of our sessions.

We teach about Reiki, and offer free help with all types of holistic healing needs.

Reiki (pronounced ray-key) deals with attunement to spiritual consciousness (rei) and life energy (ki). Traditional Usui Reiki derives from the work of Dr. Mikao Usui, a Japanese Buddhist, who lived 1865-1926.

Reiki involves laying-on of hands or related work with the human energy field (e.g., acu-points, meridians, chakras, aura), aimed to promote healing and/or spiritual development.


If you are connected with Virginia Tech, or are in the area of Blacksburg, Virginia, USA, you are encouraged to attend any of the weekly meetings of the Club where there is free training as well as help with healing issues (pain or other physical/emotional/mental difficulties).

Practicing Reiki, like tai chi, does not require any specific religious belief.

Meeting announcements are made through the club email listserv.  Please email Dr. Ed Fox at fox@vt.edu if you would like to be added to the email listserv.

For the Spring 2021 semester weekly meetings of the Reiki Club will occur each Tuesday, 5 - 6:30 pm, EST; see details below.

This will proceed throughout the fall, unless announced otherwise.

We use Zoom (or you can call in with a phone if that works better), and send energy in turn to each person who connects, after starting with an international Reiki Circle. So, people can join from anywhere on Earth.

Attendees report it is highly effective; it typically involves 8 or more people each week.

Even if you just want to join for a short session to help you, feel free to “tune in”.



= = = further details follow = = =

For the meeting Zoom link, contact Dr. Ed Fox (at fox@vt.edu).

Online meetings will take place at the usual time unless states otherwise: Tuesdays, 5 - 6:30pm

If anyone wants to receive energy but is not available at that time, please email Dr. Ed Fox (fox@vt.edu) email so you can be added to the list of those who will be sent energy during that time period.

During the online meetings, we will use the Tong Ren approach. I will explain it at the start of each meeting.

Here is a quick summary: For each person, we will call out the vertebrae or acupoints or chakras needing work, and those helping will focus on sending energy to clear the blockage there. We will sequence through the blockages for a person, and then go on to the next person.

For those who want to study more about this, see the links near the bottom of this message.

For those who want to sharpen their focus by using one of the Tong Ren dolls and hammers (not required – feel free to just concentrate or use other mechanisms), note that they can be purchased online.

-------------

Learning Reiki

This page is aimed to help those who wish to learn about Reiki and to become a Reiki practitioner. For more information in general about Reiki, refer to the many books and other Web sites on the topic.

Introduction

Treatment vs. Practice: Many people receive Reiki "treatments". Some view it as a way to have assistance with their health problems, or to relax, or to get energized. However, others want more; they are the intended audience for this page. They may wish to use or practice Reiki as part of their personal efforts to heal themselves, and possibly their family and friends. That may be out of love and concern, and/or may be to create an income stream, perhaps in connection with other activities, like massage or acupuncture.

Attunement: Those who wish to use or practice Reiki must become "attuned" to Reiki, typically through some training process that includes an attunement. The attunement takes 5 minutes to an hour, depending on the situation and on the time the person becoming attuned takes to work through the experience. It needs to occur in a private and quiet place where there should not be interruptions. (However, some teach Reiki in large classes, where others can observe the process, so they can learn what to expect.) Once attuned, a person is permanently empowered as a healer - this cannot be undone, though a person can somewhat ignore the ability. Attunement is at 3 levels - 1, 2, and 3 (or sometimes more, depending on the approach/school). Most people are trained and receive attunement only at level 1. That empowers them to heal using Reiki. Such training about other aspects of Reiki practice at level 1 can take an hour or a day or two, depending on the trainee's sensitivity, background, reading, etc. Some people experience a cleansing period after an attunement . Some people try to prepare for attunements. Doing so may help one achieve more personal growth, but is not necessary. Note also that receiving attunement and training usually involves some exchange (e.g., payment) to cover the cost of resources and the investment of time. Often a Reiki teacher remains a lifelong mentor and commits to helping in the future.

Advanced Studies: Some interested in Reiki may wish to train others, or to use Reiki as part of their personal program of spiritual growth. Often this leads to them seeking further training, and receiving attunements at other levels. This activity is a very serious one, and should only be taken by those who are mature and willing to engage in personal spiritual development and are seriously committed to helping others. Usually it takes at least 21 days after each attunement for the body to adjust, and before the next attunement can be considered. Sometimes those pursuing advanced Reiki training wind up making serious changes in their lives. To some extent they may develop sensitivities and abilities that others might consider strange, or "psychic", though in my perspective these are all quite natural and available to all. Yet, as in any learning and change process, those involved must seek balance, and must fit well into the world around them.

 

Pointers for those wanting to learn Reiki / who seek attunement

Finding a teacher: To pursue Reiki at level 1, it is necessary to find a teacher. One should identify a person who you feel comfortable with and who has been certified as a Reiki teacher. There are various directories to help in this process, managed by groups like International Association of Reiki Professionals or International Center for Reiki Training.

Author: Edward A. Fox, Level III Reiki practitioner and teacher, member International Association of Reiki Professionals

Last Updated: 2019/1/19
Email: Please send comments and suggestions to: fox@vt.edu
(c) Copyright 2003-2019 Edward A. Fox

67925.name: Relay For Life at Virginia Tech
67925.summary: Relay For Life at Virginia Tech is a year-long, record-breaking fundraising effort that benefits the American Cancer Society. Virginia Tech has had the largest Collegiate Relay For Life in the World for the decade.
67925.description_html:
Relay For Life at Virginia Tech is a community-wide, campus-based movement dedicated to eliminating cancer by living out our motto, "Ut Prosim" (That I May Serve) as we strive to raise money and awareness for the American Cancer Society. At Virginia Tech, our Relay is the largest collegiate event in the nation and has been since 2009. We are setting milestones and will continue to be leaders in this movement until we find a cure. For the past 12 years, we have raised roughly half a million dollars each year for the American Cancer Society. Since our inception at Tech in 2000-2001, we have raised over $6 million for a cure!  Join us on the Drillfield on April 25th, 2025!  

Joining our organization is simple! You have a couple of options:

1. Executive Committee: A group of highly passionate individuals that help plan many different aspects of Relay For Life. This person leads a group of peers in planning a specific aspect of Relay. Applications open around July each year!

2. Committee: Another group of highly passionate individuals that help many different aspects of Relay For Life. A committee member will be chosen by an Executive Member to join their committee to help in the planning of an aspect of Relay. Applications open early fall and spring semesters.

3. Team Captain/Participant: Participants are the people who truly make a difference with the American Cancer Society by raising funds, spreading awareness, and joining our cause. You can create and lead a team by signing up as a Team Captain. There are over 2,000 participants every year and we want you to join us by signing up at vtrelay.org. 

 

If you have any questions or wish to participate, reach us at director@vtrelay.org

420464.name: REM on Campus
420464.summary: Providing students with hands-on experience by connecting them with local small businesses and conducting consulting, financial, marketing, and management recommendations + deliverables for them.

294066.name: Remote Area Medical Chapter at Virginia Tech
294066.summary: We organize volunteers, raise funds, and network with local medical schools with a close relationship to the Remote Area Medical National Organization. We help provide free healthcare to those in remote areas with little access to healthcare.
294066.description_html: If you're looking for a meaningful way to make a difference in local communities, then check this out! Remote Area Medical at Virginia Tech offers an incredible opportunity to provide much-needed medical, vision, and dental care to remote areas. The best part? You don't need prior medical experience to get involved (you won't perform surgery or anything like that :)) ! Every month or so, Remote Area Medical or RAM organize free clinics just a few hours away from campus over a weekend, where you can join other volunteers, network with medical students and providers, and connect with patients. It's a fantastic way to gain hands-on experience, network, and truly understand the healthcare challenges in the U.S.  If this does interest you, RAM@VT is more than happy to have you join our team!

403390.name: Reproductive Freedom at Virginia Tech
403390.summary: We are a chapter of a national organization, Reproductive Freedom For All. Focused on educating Virginia Tech and surrounding areas on the history, science and rights of abortion while making active efforts towards legislation changes that support women.
403390.description_html: • We are a student-led organization, a chapter of Reproductive Freedom for All, a national nonprofit advocacy organization. We are dedicated to raising awareness about reproductive rights across different states while providing educational resources to Virginia Tech and surrounding communities on the history and science surrounding womens health care. In addition we actively engage in advocacy, focusing on legislation and community outreach to foster an environment that protects and respects womens bodily autonomy

357881.name: Residential College at West Ambler Johnston
357881.summary: The Residential College at West AJ is a unique community of 850+ students, from all years and all academic disciplines. RCWAJ is led by a live-in faculty principal and is centered on the motto, "Be Together, Not the Same."
357881.description_html: We offer something a bit different, something not for everyone, because it’s something special, something more interesting than you’ll find elsewhere on campus. The Residential College at West AJ is a unique community of 850+ students, from all years and all academic disciplines, all living together in a specialized, air-conditioned residence hall. We have a movie theater, great lounges, and classroom space right inside the building – and they’re all intended for both socializing and learning, spaces to enable mentorship and conversations about real, important things. Over 800 students make up the Residential College at West Ambler Johnston. To help create smaller, more meaningful communities, the college is divided into four houses.

77750.name: Residential Learning College at West Ambler Johnston College Council
77750.summary: The Residential College @ West Ambler Johnston College Council is responsible for the planning of residential events at the The Residential College @ West Amber Johnston.

373127.name: Residential Well-being Summer Terms
373127.summary: Gobblerconnect for Residential Well-being Summer Terms

189491.name: RHeart at Virginia Tech
189491.summary: RHeart at Virginia Tech is on a mission to prevent Sudden Cardiac Arrest (SCA) through awareness, education, and action. Our foundation provides free preventative heart screenings to young competitive athletes to test for warning signs of SCA.
189491.description_html:
Beating Strong, Living Long

RHeart at Virginia Tech is on a mission to prevent Sudden Cardiac Arrest through awareness, education, and action. Our foundation provides free preventative heart screenings to young competitive athletes to test for warning signs of Sudden Cardiac Arrest (SCA). We also strive to educate the youth about the importance of knowing how to perform CPR and use an AED. Lastly, we place AEDs in schools that cannot afford to purchase one on their own.

Preventative heart screenings are not a part of annual physical exams. RHeart fills this void by providing free heart screenings for young competitive athletes.

Founded by Virginia Tech undergraduates, RHeart is a group that strives to protect young athletes from Sudden Cardiac Arrest. In other words, an organization run for the youth by the youth.

147351.name: Rhetoric Club
147351.summary: Rhetoric Club is a professional development organization for students interested in rhetoric and writing at Virginia Tech, focused on success, fellowship, and community engagement.
147351.description_html:
The Rhetoric Club provides a forum for rhetorical inquiry and support for students interested in the multidisciplinary study of rhetoric. Club activities include workshops, guest speakers, publication and conference support, and community engagement for the study of rhetoric. The club's goals are as follows:

  • To situate the student rhetoric community within scholarly conversations
  • To provide professional development regarding publications, conferences, and scholarly behavior
  • To build connections between students and faculty
  • To provide educational advice for handling graduate school
  • To assess perceptions of needs within the student rhetoric community

357883.name: Rhizome
357883.summary:
Thinking Globally, Acting Locally 
LLC in the CID-LLP

403391.name: Rho Epsilon Iota
403391.summary: Rho Epsilon Iota is the nation’s first premier real estate fraternity. We are dedicated to fostering the next generation of real estate professionals by creating an inclusive learning, growth, and professional development environment.
403391.description_html:
Rho Epsilon Iota is the nation’s first premier real estate fraternity, powered by FIRE (Future Investors in Real Estate). We are dedicated to fostering the next generation of real estate professionals by creating an inclusive environment for learning, growth, and professional development.

Co-Presidents:

  • Hasan Rizvi
  • Aaron Labatch

 

Our Mission:

  • National Expansion: Become the future of professional real estate fraternities, nationally.
  • Inclusive Environment: Create a space for real estate minds to flourish regardless of prior experience.
  • Professional Advancement: Promote the professional advancement of all aspiring real estate professionals through commercial, residential, industrial, land, and special-use programs.
  • High Standards: Uphold the highest standards of honesty, equality, representation, knowledge, and professionalism on college campuses and within the community.

 

Core Values:

 

  • Honesty: Emphasize ethical behavior and transparency in all real estate dealings to build trust and credibility among members and with external stakeholders.
  • Innovation: Foster creativity and forward-thinking in the real estate market. Encourage the adoption of new technologies and strategies to stay ahead in a competitive industry.
  • Community: Highlight the importance of contributing to and improving local communities through real estate initiatives. This involves sustainable development, community service projects, or educational outreach programs.

294067.name: Riichi Mahjong Association at Virginia Tech
294067.summary: The Riichi Mahjong Association at Virginia Tech focuses on an Asian board game - Mahjong, be specific, Riichi Mahjong. The goal of VTMA is collecting Mahjong players in VT and Blacksburg to enjoy the fun of mahjong and let more people know mahjong.
294067.description_html:
Riichi Mahjong Association at Virginia Tech - VTMA focus on a popular Asian board game - Mahjong (Very famous in China, Japan, and other East Asian countries). We recommend this game to anyone interested in Asian or Mahjong culture. If you are a big fan of Chinese or Japanese culture, this is a good chance to learn more about it through VTMA! VTMA has weekly Riichi Mahjong meet-ups for every weekend and tutorials that covered most of the knowledge of mahjong and Riichi Mahjong. We also hold tournaments every semester. Let's enjoy the fun of mahjong!

To receive our emails, you can fill out this form: https://forms.gle/CkNiesnw8A1nhDn48

Discord: https://discord.gg/QtnrZSRGBX

145758.name: Roanoke Graduate Student Association
145758.summary: RGSA is a VT student organization that works to serve and advocate for the graduate life & wellbeing of graduate students living and/or working in Roanoke!
145758.description_html:
The purpose of the RGSA is:

  • To advocate for and support the graduate life and wellbeing of graduate students of Virginia Tech living and/or working in Roanoke
  • To address, support, and promote issues and concerns of the VTC Health Sciences and Technology (HS&T) Campus graduate student community by serving as a liaison between the Graduate and Professional Student Senate, university administration, and the HS&T graduate students.
  • To facilitate professional development and scholarship of the students at the HS&T campus by hosting career development events
  • To provide opportunities for graduate students to develop and hone leadership skills
  • To support the connection between Roanoke graduate students and the community through outreach partnerships
  • To complement Virginia Tech initiatives towards University Diversity Equity and Inclusion
  • To foster a sense of community among Roanoke graduate students

For more information on RGSA happenings & events, check out our website!

167641.name: RoboGrinder at Virginia Tech
167641.summary: RoboMaster North America is a robotics competition created for young engineers around the world. Our team builds around 4 robots for the competition every year to ensure we remain competitive against the other teams.
167641.description_html:
Executive Summary

This is an excellent opportunity for the ECE department and Virginia Tech. RoboMaster North America is an annual competition that attracts teams throughout the United States and across the world. As electrical and computer engineers at Virginia Tech, we created a team to attend this competition.

Benefit for VT

Last year more than ten thousand audience members came to the championship matches, and over 6 million online viewers tuned in. Participating in this competition will show the public that Virginia Tech is a world-class engineering university that gives students a high-quality education.

EVA

In this competition, students will learn and apply knowledge and hands-on skills of programming, networking, designing, and developing sensors by building robots. This is an international competition. So we are able to learn experiences from other teams.

Team

Our team members are from different disciplines and have a variety of backgrounds. Most of the current team members have hands-on work experience from different labs and competitions. The goal is to have 30 registered team members, with at least 10 junior level students. Thus, we will have enough students to form parallel prototyping sub-teams. We are also focused on hiring more female team members to maintain the diversity of our team.

Skills

We have students experienced in drone operation, 3D modeling and radio controlling. Our team members are familiar with different programming languages (C, C++, Java, Python) and compiling environments (GCC, GDB). We have worked with motors and sensors extensively. We are the only team that has two members who did the internship at RoboMasters last summer, so we have a competitive edge.

Join US

Please go to our official website: https://www.robogrinder.org/join-us/ and submit your application to your desired branch. Our operations team will review your materials and invite you for an interview. The final offer will be made based on performance during the process.

413627.name: Robot in 3 Days at Virginia Tech
413627.summary: RI3D at VT spends 72 hours after the launch of a new FIRST FRC challenge building a competitive robot to create a resource for high school students worldwide.
413627.description_html: Robot in 3 Days at Virginia Tech is a student-led, student-run organization that spends 72 straight hours during the winter semester designing, prototyping, and fabricating a robot for FIRST's FRC challenge. The ultimate goal of RI3D at Virginia Tech is to create an online resource for high school students to gain inspiration and develop rapid-prototyping skills, as well as to help develop students into top-notch Virginia Tech engineers.

69088.name: Rock Climbing Club at Virginia Tech
69088.summary: The climbing club is a student organization dedicated to helping people experience the joy of climbing. The club provides opportunities to meet other climbers and clinics to demonstrate some of the skills needed. Check the roster for officer emails!
69088.description_html:
The climbing club at Virginia Tech is a student organization dedicated to helping people of all skill levels experience the joy of climbing. The club provides opportunities to meet and climb with other climbers, clinics to build your skills as a climber, and organizes trips to get out on the rock. Club meetings are open to anyone who would like to come. Check the roster (left side bar) for officer emails. Follow the instagram @climb_vt for updates regarding meetings. Our primary form of communication is GroupMe, so feel free to reach out in order to be added.

Our primary means of communication is through our Instagram @climb_vt.  Please follow the instagram to find the most up to date information, announcements, events, and what is going on in the club! 

Check our Instagram or GroupMe for regular updates about club meeting times and locations!

80003.name: Rocketry at Virginia Tech
80003.summary: High power rocketry club at Virginia Tech, competing in an intercollegiate rocketry competition.
80003.description_html:
Rocketry at Virginia Tech is a competition engineering design team affiliated with the Virginia Tech Department of Aerospace and Ocean Engineering. The aim of the club is to create an environment for students to learn and work together building, launching, and experimenting with high power rockets. The club also serves to aid those who wish to pursue high power certification by connecting students with the local rocketry club, New River Valley Rocketry (NRVR), and chapters of both Tripoli Rocketry Association (TRA) and the National Association of Rocketry (NAR).

Each year we participate in the Intercollegiate Rocket Engineering Competition (IREC) hosted by ESRA out in Texas. We compete in the Commercial off the shelf (COTS) category and manufacture a high power rocket with a scientific payload. The competition goal is to launch our rocket to 10,000 feet as accurately as possible.

Be sure to check out our website for more information, and feel free to contact us at rocketry.vt@gmail.com with any questions or comments.

We do not accept membership through Gobblerconnect, please check out our website for more information about our recruitment process.

69127.name: Rotaract Club
69127.summary: The Rotaract Club provides an outlet for students to participate in international and local service projects, fundraising events, club socials, and leadership training. Rotaract also supports projects of the local Rotary club.
69127.description_html: Rotaract members are "partners in service" with our sponsoring Rotary Club. Rotaract addresses our community’s physical and social needs while promoting international understanding and peace through a framework of friendship and service. In addition to community service projects, Rotaract offers students opportunities for growing professionally and networking.  Beyond the club level there are district conferences and training seminars, study exchange program opportunities, and the Rotary International Convention.

178396.name: Roundnet at Virginia Tech
178396.summary: Our mission is to foster a community at Virginia Tech around the sport of roundnet.
178396.description_html: The purpose of this Club/Organization is to provide an opportunity for students of Virginia Tech to learn and play the sport of roundnet in a friendly and competitive environment. Our goals are to set up open campus wide tournaments to promote our club as well as the sport of roundnet, to anyone who is interested. We plan to represent Virginia Tech at other college campuses during intercollegiate tournaments across the nation, including the official College Tour Series sponsored by Spikeball. We also will seek to create a casual environment of play for those who are interested in that. We will equip members with all they need to be a successful roundnet Player. We just won a National Championship so we proved we are a worthy club and definitely feel qualified for some more funding next academic year.

400651.name: Rummi Klub
400651.summary: A fun, loving, and stress free environment for students of all backgrounds to come together and play rummikub together.
400651.description_html: A fun, loving, and stress free environment for students of all backgrounds to come together and play rummikub together. This club will foster a screen less environment where people can collaborate outside of schoolwork and take much needed breaks.

413628.name: RunTheBurg
413628.summary: No signups. No limits. Just vibes, pace, & people. Thurs 6:30pm / Sat 10am. Blacksburg, VA.
413628.description_html: Our run club is a casual, fun, and social community that welcomes runners, joggers, and walkers of all paces. We believe that movement should be inclusive and enjoyable for everyone, whether you're chasing personal records or just out for a stroll. Through group runs or post-run social gatherings, our objective is to create a space where people can connect, build friendships, and share a passion for fitness in a supportive, low-pressure environment. Our goal is to celebrate diversity, promote wellness, and ensure that everyone feels part of the community, regardless of their experience or background.

72135.name: Russian Speaking Student Association at Virginia Tech
72135.summary: The Russian Speaking Student Association (RSSA) at Virginia Tech promotes language and cultures of Russia, fostering cultural exchange and appreciation through diverse cultural events.
72135.description_html:
The Russian Speaking Student Association (RSSA) at Virginia Tech promotes language and cultures of Russia, fostering cultural exchange and appreciation through diverse cultural events.

 

We host a variety of activities, including cultural workshops, and social events, embracing the unique heritage of Russia and many other CIS countries. 

 

RSSA is an inclusive community dedicated to celebrating the diverse languages and cultures of Russia and (current and former) Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS). We welcome students of all proficiency levels in Russian!

 

Follow us on insta @vt_ruslanguageclub

359828.name: RWB District 1
359828.summary: This organization page is a resource to residents in Hillcrest, Ambler Johnston, O'Shaughnessy and the CID LLC facilities for community programming through Residential Well-Being.

399626.name: RWB Student Leader Support Fund
399626.summary: A place for SSLs to create programming for current Student Leaders.
399626.description_html: A place for SSLs to create programming for current Student Leaders.

100565.name: SailBOT at Virginia Tech
100565.summary: The AutoBoat team at VT designs and manufactures fully autonomous robotic sailboats and autonomous high power electric motor boats for the International Robotic Sailing Regatta and Promoting Electric Propulsion (PEP) competitions respectively.
100565.description_html:
The AutoBoat (formerly SailBOT) team at VT designs and manufactures fully autonomous robotic sailboats and autonomous high-power electric motor boats for the International Robotic Sailing Regatta and Promoting Electric Propulsion (PEP) competitions respectively.

 

Join our Discord server to get updated on what happening with the team: https://discord.gg/e34cdWdKbG

 

The AutoBoat team at VT designs and manufactures fully autonomous robotic sailboats and autonomous high-power electric motor boats for the International Robotic Sailing Regatta and Promoting Electric Propulsion (PEP) competitions respectively. AutoBoat at VT is divided into 6 sub-teams: Mechanical, Electrical, Software, Naval Architecture/Ocean Engineering, Sail, and Marketing/ Outreach. Each contributes to the design and creation of both our autonomous sailboat and high-power electric motorboat.

_____________

The Naval Architecture (NavArch) sub-team is focused on the durability, maneuverability, and seakeeping capabilities of each hull. Using Orca3D and other CAD tools, they design and optimize hull shapes around these qualities. Throughout the year, this sub-team works on hull designs, fiberglass layups, structural repairs, hull ballasting, and hydrodynamic modifications to enhance performance on the water.

The Propulsion sub-team is responsible for the design and fabrication of each vessel's propulsion system. They utilize tools such as SailCAD and principles of airfoil theory to optimize sail shape and rigging for efficient propulsion and control while overseeing the hands-on research and construction of sails. Oversight is also required for the propulsion on the other hulls where focus on propellers, their assembly, and understanding of fluid dynamics are key to success. 

The Mechanical sub-team is responsible for the design and construction of the boat’s physical structure and mechanisms, ensuring lightweight, watertight, and battle-tested capability for competition. Their workflow includes CAD modeling, MATLAB analysis, and hands-on fabrication using 3D printing, CNC machining, and laser-cutting. The Mechanical sub-team acts as the backbone of the boat, bringing together contributions from every team to form a cohesive product.

The Software sub-team develops the autonomous navigation systems, computer vision algorithms, and control software that enable our boats to sail and navigate independently. They work with Python, C++, ROS, Gazebo, YOLO, and Docker to create an intelligent autopilot software package.

The Telemetry sub-team develops and maintains custom ground station software to control and monitor our boats from the shore. They also maintain the full codebase for our website.

The Hardware (ECE) sub-team develops the infrastructure to bridge the barrier between software algorithms and the real-world constraints of our boats. They design and manufacture custom PCBs; collect data from sensors and actuators; and develop low-level firmware to interface with motors, pumps, and other electromechanical systems. The Electrical sub-team’s workflow includes PCB design in KiCAD, electronics simulations in LTSpice, embedded programming in C++, and prototype development using tools like oscilloscopes and logic analyzers.

The Business sub-team handles team outreach, sponsor relations, budget management, and team marketing. Tasks within this sub-team seek to fill in the administrative or financial needs of the whole team. Their work in this sub-team is also in conjunction with one or more of the other technical sub-teams of AutoBoat.


The team consists primarily of undergraduate students and is open to all academic levels and majors with no application required to join!

69244.name: Sailing Club at Virginia Tech
69244.summary: Welcome to the Sailing Club at Virginia Tech! We have options to sail recreationally or competitively, and we do not require any sailing experience to join. Feel free to reach out if you are interested!
69244.description_html: We are a group of people enthusiastic about sailing.  We sail for fun almost every Sunday at Claytor Lake State Park which is less than half an hour away. We also have members who travel to compete at regattas several times a semester.  If you look in the documents tab on the left you will find a powerpoint that tells you basically everything you will need to know about the club.  Feel free to reach out whenever if you any questions or are interested in joining. Any level of sailor is welcome!

63265.name: SalsaTech at Virginia Tech
63265.summary: SalsaTech hosts free lessons and socials weekly for students of Virginia Tech, as well as the Blacksburg community. We teach several styles of Latin dance, such as salsa, bachata, merengue, cumbia, and rueda.
63265.description_html: We at SalsaTech aim to create safe educational and social environments to provide the opportunity for individuals to learn about Latin dance, music, and culture. We teach dance lessons weekly (salsa, bachata, merengue, cumbia, rueda, ect), as well as specific styles of some of these dances. We host weekly dance socials to give people a chance to practice, learn, and have fun in a social environment. We strive to host an open and inclusive environment where individuals can grow, create connections and friendships in the Blacksburg community, and learn something new. We have an enduring focus on diversity, equity, and inclusion, and do whatever we can to provide free or low-cost opportunities to dance and learn in order to support this goal.

65764.name: Saudi Student Club at Virginia Tech
65764.summary: We aim to promote the culture of Saudi Arabia, foster trust, and embrace volunteering. Through events showcasing our traditions and values, we bridge gaps and build connections. We strive for cultural appreciation, unity, inclusion, and diversity.
65764.description_html:
Our club was established in 2006 by Abdulsalam Alsuliman and has been registered in Virginia Tech and the Saudi Arabian Culture Mission (SACM) in Washington DC for more than 17 years.

Our student organization is dedicated to representing Saudi Arabia, its rich culture, and traditions. Through a variety of events and activities, we aim to showcase the vibrant aspects of our country and foster a deeper understanding of our society among Americans and international students in Blacksburg.

One of our primary missions is to educate and enlighten others about the core values that define Saudi Arabian culture. We believe in promoting mutual respect, openness, and trust among our members and the broader community. By engaging in meaningful conversations, cultural exchanges, and collaborative efforts, we aim to bridge gaps and build connections that promote cultural appreciation and unity.

Volunteering lies at the heart of our club's vision. We recognize the transformative power of giving back to the community and strive to instill a strong sense of civic responsibility among our members. Through various volunteer initiatives, we actively seek opportunities to make a positive impact, extend a helping hand, and contribute to the betterment of society.

By embodying these values and dedicating ourselves to showcasing the richness of Saudi Arabian culture, we aim to create an inclusive and welcoming environment where individuals from all backgrounds can come together, learn from one another, and celebrate diversity.

Together, we aspire to foster cultural awareness, promote intercultural understanding, and inspire a global community that embraces diversity, values inclusivity, and works towards a more connected world.

335192.name: Save the Children Action Network at Virginia Tech
335192.summary: The Save the Children Action Network (SCAN) was created to expand early childhood education in the US, help vulnerable children worldwide, and keep children safe at the US-Mexico border. Our goal is to give every child a strong start in life!
335192.description_html: Here at the Virginia Tech Chapter of SCAN, we inform our local and state community about the struggles many children in the US face, advocate for the vulnerable children in the US, and encourage citizens to be more active in our democratic process. If you're interested in helping children, politics, your community, or want to be an informed citizen, SCAN is the perfect club for you!

379911.name: SBIO Graduate Students Association
379911.summary: The mission of the Sustainable Biomaterials Graduate Student Association is to serve the graduate students of the Department of Sustainable Biomaterials by enhancing their academic, professional, and social belonging.
379911.description_html:
SBGSA will accomplish these goals in following ways: 

  • Peer-mentoring program: The purpose of peer mentoring is to build healthy student-to-student relationships and support incoming students settling into the new program. The more senior students will attend the student sessions to assist more junior students and the department will provide support for these support groups, e.g., space, food, and recognition of student volunteers.
  • We will register our department with the International Society of Sustainability Professionals (ISSP). ISSP is a leading professional association of sustainability practitioners. They offer an Education Partners Program for universities and students which is designed for supporting students who aspire to pursue a career in sustainability. Their members (students and faculty) will be able to earn a Sustainability Excellence Associate (SEA) credential. This would offer multi-faceted opportunities to SBIO students by educating them on sustainability issues, building their leadership and teamwork skills, and connecting them with sustainability professionals which would open new doors for students’ future employment. SBIO already enjoys a good relationship with the Forest Products Society, we will extend this partnership to our organization.
  • It is hoped that our organization will enhance the social belonging of graduate students through connections and common interests. The aim is to create a student-led community where everyone, returning and incoming students, feels at home. We will strategically identify students’ needs and host regular meet-and-greet events to cater to their needs.

113128.name: Schiffert Health Center
113128.summary: Schiffert Health Center’s mission is to ensure the delivery of high-quality, accessible, cost-effective, and culturally competent medical care and health promotion for Virginia Tech students.
113128.description_html:
Schiffert Health Center’s mission is to ensure the delivery of high-quality, accessible, cost-effective, and culturally competent medical care and health promotion for Virginia Tech students.

In support of Virginia Tech’s mission to educate the whole person, Schiffert Health Center promotes the current and future wellbeing of our student-patients through the provision of nationally accredited health care and health education to promote healthy lifestyles. Our services are cost-effective and responsive to student needs so as to reduce the impact of illness and other health concerns on student success at Virginia Tech.

Other Key Objectives

  • To educate students in the skills of self-care and wellness, and prepare them to be effective healthcare consumers
  • To assist members of the university community in the management of health-related crises
  • To continually improve the quality of staff, facilities, and service delivery
  • To continually assess the needs of students in an effort to provide relevant services

414671.name: ScholarDOCs
414671.summary: ScholarDocs is an after-school program exposing underserved high school students to medicine, focusing on neuroscience and cardiology.
414671.description_html: ScholarDocs aims to inspire and empower underserved high school students by providing early exposure to medicine through hands-on learning in neuroscience, cardiology, and other specialties, fostering interest, equity, and diversity in the future of healthcare.

137017.name: School of Architecture + Design
137017.summary: The School of Architecture + Design houses four majors - Architecture, Industrial Design, Interior Design, and Landscape Architecture

362518.name: School of Neuroscience Student Ambassadors
362518.summary: The School of Neuroscience Student Ambassadors is an organization of undergraduate students who are dedicated to establishing a community within the school through peer mentoring, event planning, and acting as representatives for the department.

166129.name: School of Performing Arts
166129.summary: We believe in the transformative power of the performing arts.

70369.name: Science and Technology Studies Graduate Student Organization
70369.summary: An organization for graduate students interested in science and technology issues at the intersection of philosophy, history, sociology, and policy.
70369.description_html: We are an organization for students interested in science and technology issues at the intersection of philosophy, history, sociology, and policy. While it is largely comprised of students in the Master's and PhD programs in Science and Technology in Society, the organization is open to anyone.

63013.name: Science Fiction and Fantasy Club at Virginia Tech
63013.summary: The Science Fiction and Fantasy Club at Virginia Tech exists to promote and create science fiction and fantasy, in various media forms, to the Virginia Tech and surrounding communities.
63013.description_html:
TL;DR Welcome to the club for science fiction and fantasy media, from games to books to movies and everything in between, and the place to go for those who'd like to get into Dungeons & Dragons (D&D, DnD), Magic: The Gathering (MtG), and the like!

The Science Fiction and Fantasy Club at Virginia Tech exists to promote and create science fiction and fantasy, in various media forms, to the Virginia Tech and surrounding communities (Blacksburg, Christiansburg, and the New River Valley Region).

Regular meetings are Thursdays at 7:30 on the first floor of New Classroom Building. If you wish to get involved or receive updates about the club, including meeting location for our first meeting, you can join our Discord server here: https://discord.gg/VpjppVX. Additionally, there are a wide variety of weekend events. Attendance to regular meetings and many of the weekend events is open and free.

Founded in 1982 by students with a passion for science fiction and fantasy, VTSFFC brings together people with interests in viewing, discussing, and creating works of those genres. The club's events include movie outings, game nights, picnics, trips to book fairs, role playing games, tabletop games and a multitude of other activities. One of VTSFFC's main outreach activities is volunteering at, planning, and producing conventions.

171092.name: Science Olympiad at Virginia Tech
171092.summary: Science Olympiad at Virginia Tech (SO@VT) is a non-profit student chapter of Virginia Science Olympiad (VASO) that hosts tournaments for middle and high school Science Olympiad teams to compete in across various STEM topics.
171092.description_html:
Our core group of officers plan annual Invitational and Regional Science Olympiad tournaments for middle and high school students interested in various STEM topics — ranging from entomology, to optics, to engineering their own electronic devices. Our influence extends beyond Virginia, seeing teams travel from across the nation to compete in our tournaments. These tournaments are held with the support of 100+ collegiate volunteers.

 

 

Additionally, SO@VT is dedicated to a number of STEM & SO outreach initiatives via science fairs, webinars, and more, particularly focusing on the SWVA region.

 

 

VT News 2025 Feature!

294068.name: Science Policy Education and Advocacy Club
294068.summary: SPEAC empowers graduate and undergraduate students to connect science and policy through workshops, networking, and real-world engagement. Join us to build communication skills, explore science-policy careers, and make an impact.
294068.description_html:
The mission of SPEAC is to (1) educate members about careers and opportunities in science policy and highlight the important role that scientists and engineers can have in shaping legislation and policy, (2) help members develop the skills to communicate science and policy ideas effectively to both technical and non-technical audiences, and (3) empower members to get involved and have a voice in government and policy. SPEAC is a vehicle for students to explore issues at the intersection of science and policy, expose them to the process of how policy is created and how they can get involved, and introduce them to professionals who are currently working in the area of science policy.

SPEAC is primarily comprised of students at the graduate level, but we welcome motivated undergraduates and post-doctoral researchers.

335184.name: Scientistas at Virginia Tech
335184.summary: Scientistas at Virginia Tech strives to empower, support, and connect undergraduate and graduate women in STEM. We offer mentorship, workshop, and networking opportunities that can empower women and help them succeed with their current and future goals.
335184.description_html:
Scientistas at Virginia Tech is a chapter of the Scientista foundation that strives to empower, support, and connect undergraduate and graduate women in science, technology, engineering, mathematics, and medicine (STEMM). We offer mentorship, workshop, and networking opportunities. Our goal is to provide beneficial resources that can empower women in STEMM and help them succeed with both their current and future endeavors.  

We aim to host workshops on career development, applying to graduate school, networking, and more. We also foster our community by hosting study nights, game nights, book clubs, and more! As a fairly new organization, we are excited to further develop who we are and to incorporate new things based on the needs of our members.

414672.name: SciMed
414672.summary: SciMed is a student-run group that empowers students to pursue their research interests. We aim to supplement students' normal curricular research lessons with more specific workshops that can build the skills students will be expected to know when condu
414672.description_html: SciMed is dedicated to familiarizing medical students with the intricacies of scientific writing. Through engaging workshops, our aim is to enhance students' proficiency in crafting compelling case reports, literature reviews, and full research papers. We provide guidance on honing the skills necessary for effective scientific writing, equipping students with the ability to conduct thorough searches for topics that align with their interests. Join us as we empower medical students to excel in the art of scientific writing creation and exploration.

65765.name: Scuba Club at Virginia Tech
65765.summary: The Scuba Club at Virginia Tech promotes SCUBA diving and dive safety through classes, trips, training, and meetings throughout the school year.
65765.description_html:
The Scuba Club at Virginia Tech promotes SCUBA diving and dive safety through classes, trips, training, and meetings throughout the school year. Looking to get certified? Sign up for one of our classes! Want to go diving in the area, or go on a trip to somewhere warm and tropical? Come to our meetings/website to learn more! Feel free to join our Facebook group, subscribe to our mailing list, and fill out our interest form to get involved.

Website: https://sites.google.com/vt.edu/scvt/home?authuser=0

Facebook Group: www.facebook.com/groups/scubaclubvt/

96855.name: SECL - Student Staff
96855.summary: Helping students employed by the department of Student Engagement and Campus Life develop professional skills through training.

400652.name: Second Degree Ultimate Frisbee Club
400652.summary: Open, developmental ultimate frisbee team at Virginia Tech
400652.description_html:
Second Degree seeks to provide a structured, competitive environment and help develop skills to play Ultimate Frisbee and is open to all. We welcome individuals from all cultures and backgrounds and seek to continue to grow the sport of Ultimate while promoting teamwork, collaboration, and community.

We practice three times a week on either the IM fields (next to the bubble) or the lacrosse fields and go to ~3 tournaments per semester. Practices are encouraged, but not required. You do not need to have any frisbee experience to join the team. 

Fall semester is our pre-season when tournaments don't officially count and new players can learn fundamentals. Spring is the official season and when we compete in sanctioned tournaments under USA Ultimate, an umbrella organization that regulates ultimate across the US.

Please reach out to a captain if you are interested in playing for us!

391622.name: Securitas
391622.summary: The Securitas Living-Learning Community is for human-centered innovators who will work across disciplines to build, manage and safeguard the cyber spaces of the future.

379801.name: Seek Christian Community at Virginia Tech
379801.summary: We are a small Christian community that welcomes everyone from every faith, background, and walk of life. Together we want to seek answers to life’s questions.
379801.description_html:
We seek to provide a safe and welcoming place for community to enable students from all backgrounds to explore their faith and to experience, learn, and share the love of Christ. Together, we want to seek answers to life’s questions and what it means to be Christian in the  world today.

We host weekly Bible studies, free community dinners, and slacklining. All our events are in our calendar and we announce and chat on our Discord server. Links can be found at links.vtseek.org

420466.name: Semiconductor Student Alliance at Virginia Tech
420466.summary: The Semiconductor Student Allianceregistered student organization dedicated to building awareness and engagement in the semiconductor industry. We are to all majors, including but not limited to ECE, ME, ChemE, MSE, CS, and ISE.
