    TPED annually attends the International Association of Amusement Parks and Attractions (IAAPA) trade show in Orlando, where students are given the opportunity to speak to and network with countless companies covering every aspect of the industry.

  • ASTM F24 on Amusement Rides and Devices
    TPED annually attends conferences for the ASTM F24 subcommittee on amusement rides and devices, where students can sit in on and participate with meetings discussing regulations that govern the design of rides. This is an excellent opportunity for networking and learning more about the industry’s technical design standards.

  • General Assembly Meetings (GAMs)
    TPED GAMs are scheduled periodically to bring the general assembly together and discuss club updates, industry news, and fun activities!

 

We are open to all majors and all years, and there are no fees nor commitments to be a member. You can pick and choose how involved you want to be: are you only interested in park trips? That’s fine! You want to participate in design competitions? Sign up! Just join our club, attend a general meeting, get on our email list, and you’ll be all set to sign up for anything that interests you. And want to be as active as possible? Our point system grants our most active members in the club extra privileges such as special pricing for trips and access to exclusive events.

408594.name: Theme Park Management Association
408594.summary: The Theme Park Management Association (TPMA) at Virginia Tech connects students with the theme park industry through networking, events, and exposure to operations, marketing, and guest experience. TPMA offers valuable insights and hands-on opportunities

74144.name: Theta Chi Fraternity
74144.summary: Fraternity colonized at Virginia Tech in 1971. Members build strong bonds of brotherhood through philanthropic endeavors and social functions.
74144.description_html:
Theta Chi Society, as it was then known, was founded at Norwich University, Norwich, Vermont, at nine o'clock on Thursday evening, April 10, 1856. We are one of the oldest men’s college fraternities in North America.

Our motto is "An Assisting Hand," something we strive to exemplify every day both within our organization and the Virginia Tech community. Every fall, we hold a philanthropic event called G.I. Theta Chi, which supports the United Services Organizations. This nonprofit organization strengthens America’s military service members by keeping them connected to family, home and country, throughout their service to the nation. We also participate in a variety of other organization's events to help support their causes.

The Eta Lambda chapter is currently comprised of 127 active members. 

For recruiting information please email rushthetachivt@gmail.com

75873.name: Theta Delta Chi
75873.summary: Theta Delta Chi is an international fraternity with charges at more than 30 universities across the world. Our members strive to be the best versions of themselves through hard work and community service.
75873.description_html: Since 1847, Theta Delta Chi believes that it is the duty of every member to improve himself intellectually, morally, and socially through friendship. TDX is an international fraternity that fields Charges at over thirty universities in the US and Canada.

69076.name: Theta Xi Fraternity
69076.summary: Theta Xi is one of North America’s oldest social fraternities and the only such organization founded during the Civil War. Headquartered in Atlanta, Georgia, Theta Xi services Chapters and Colonies all over the United States. Our successes and diversity
69076.description_html:
This organization has not yet completed the steps to be an official Registered Student Organization (RSO), but the organization has a provisional recognition status for the Fall 2025 semester, in partnership with the Fraternity and Sorority Life. Under this provisional status, the organization has received permission to recruit members and operate on campus as they complete their requirements. If you have additional questions, please email gogreek@vt.edu

 

Our members believe in shared fraternal values of:

  • Leadership
  • Learning
  • Integrity
  • Achievement
  • Responsibility
  • Self-Esteem
  • Diversity
  • Brotherhood

Theta Xi Fraternity is also a national leader in the leadership, educational, and social development of its members. The Fraternity offers a comprehensive new member education program called Alpha Nine and countless educational programs for its members. Theta Xi is the only National Fraternity to receive two Association of Fraternity Advisors (AFA) “Excellence in Programming” awards; one for Values into Action (Values training) and then second for Benchmarks of Excellence (Chapter Operations training).

357896.name: Thrive
357896.summary: In the Thrive Living-Learning Community, students will leverage their strengths to create a truly personalized, one-of-a-kind Virginia Tech experience.

65795.name: Trail and Ultrarunning Club at Virginia Tech
65795.summary: We are a group of enthusiastic students whose passions lie wherever running trails takes us. Many of us focus on training for ultramarathons, but we welcome runners of any ability to join us!
65795.description_html:
Welcome to UltraVT! Every week we meet at the Pylons to drive to Pandapas to run and enjoy local trails. Beyond this weekly jaunt, we regularly get together to train, to have adventures, and to socialize. The easiest way to get involved is to join the organization here. Feel free to reach out with any questions!

At group runs, you can expect a 4-8 mile adventure completed at your own pace. We stick together, chat a lot, and regroup at every intersection on the trails.

Checkout the website https://ultravt.gitlab.io for more relevant information and to see the group chat for the team!

357897.name: Transfer Experience
357897.summary: The Transfer Experience living-learning community is specifically designed to meet the needs of students who transfer to Virginia Tech from a community college or another four-year institution.
357897.description_html:
Transfer Experience: A Living-Learning Program at Virginia Tech

The Transfer Experience living-learning community is specifically designed to meet the needs of students who transfer to Virginia Tech from a community college or another four-year institution. Transfer Experience creates an environment where they can live with and among other transfer students and will provide connections to a variety of campus resources. Throughout the year, activities, events, and programs designed in collaboration with community members will assist transfer students in navigating a new environment and meeting the goals they have for the coming academic year.

138685.name: Triangle Fraternity
138685.summary: Triangle seeks to maintain a fraternity of engineers, architects and scientists. It shall carry out its purpose by establishing chapters that develop balanced men who cultivate high moral character, foster lifelong friendships, and live honest lives.
138685.description_html:
The objectives of Triangle Fraternity are as follows:

  • To help develop the highest standards of personal integrity and character,
  • To foster and provide an intellectual, mature environment for its members through individual and group effort and through the mutual companionship of men with similar professional interests and goals,
  • To foster and provide the broadening experience of fraternity living with its social and moral challenges and responsibilities for the individual and the chapter,
  • To recognize and support the objectives and goals of the alma mater and those of the community through responsible participation and action,
  • To help bridge the gap between undergraduate study and the vocation of the individual in industry, the academic world or government,
  • To foster and maintain a bond of fraternal brotherhood through a continuing program of activity for the alumni, and
  • To bring into focus the elements of planned progress for the betterment of mankind

114520.name: True Colors at Virginia Tech
114520.summary: True Colors is a space for anyone student at VT who identifies as non-cisgender (transgender, non-binary, etc.), gender non-conforming, and/or gender questioning, or otherwise part of the trans community
114520.description_html:
TrueColors at Virginia Tech is a space for anyone in the Virginia Tech, Blacksburg, and/or New River Valley communities/areas who identifies as non-cisgender (transgender, non-binary, etc.), gender nonconforming, and/or gender questioning, or otherwise part of the trans community. If this sounds like you, we would love for you to join us!

The group is primarily focused on fostering social connection within the local trans community, but we also strive to provide peer support, promote meaningful discussion, and become active in the community. We want to help amplify trans voices and experiences in the Virginia Tech and NRV community as we seek out acceptance and inclusion in varying aspects of life.

238387.name: Turfgrass Club
238387.summary: Turfgrass Club affords students interested in Turfgrass Science an opportunity to travel and represent Virginia Tech at national conferences, network with industry officials, and helps prepare students for a career in Turfgrass Management.
238387.description_html: Turfgrass Club provides students interested in Turfgrass Science opportunities to travel and represent Virginia Tech at national conferences, network with industry professionals, and helps prepare students for careers in Turfgrass Management. Turfgrass Club is also involved in giving back to our local community in the NRV through service-learning projects.

105187.name: Turkish Student Association
105187.summary: Turkish Student Association is a social and cultural organization created to promote awareness about Turkish culture and appreciation for cultural diversity at Virginia Tech.
105187.description_html:
Turkish Student Association is a social and cultural organization created to promote awareness about Turkish culture at Virginia Tech. To showcase our culture, we attend and organize several events throughout the year. We also help new students adapt to life in the USA and foster intercultural enrichment by offering a glimpse of our culture in several events.

Watch our board members' introduction video below.

TSA Board Members Introduction

 

TSA Cultural Demonstration

147352.name: Turning Point USA
147352.summary: Turning Point USA at Virginia Tech is a political organization that aims to educate and mobilize students to preserve liberty on our campus and engage in the political system through voting and activism.
147352.description_html:
Join Turning Point USA at Virginia Tech!

Turning Point USA at Virginia Tech exists to educate and mobilize students to preserve liberty on our college campus and throughout our nation. We hold weekly tabling and activism events, bi-weekly meetings, speaker events, and student trainings. TPUSA@VT works to identify and irradicate constitutional violations on our college campus, register students to vote, and to offer nationwide conferences in order to equip conservative students on our campus to be effective activists.
https://share.hsforms.com/1JkE4NxoYQsq3iM2bcsDFag8mopn

357893.name: Ujima
357893.summary: The Ujima Living-Learning Community (LLC) places a special emphasis on understanding the unique experiences of Black/African-Americans in society, including their experiences in college.
357893.description_html:
Focusing on cultural enrichment and academic excellence, our community allows students with similar interests to partake in programming and dialogue surrounding Black/African-American culture.

 

The Ujima Living-Learning Community (LLC) is named after an essential concept in African philosophy and the third principle of Kwanzaa. Ujima (pronounced oo-JEE-mah) means collective work and responsibility - to build and maintain our community together and make our brothers’ and sisters’ problems our problems and solve them together. Ujima, as principle and practice, also means that we are collectively responsible for our victories and achievements as much as we are for our failures and setbacks.

 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tC2XnVUHpwU

95654.name: UKirk Ministry at Virginia Tech
95654.summary: UKirk Ministry at Virginia Tech is located in Cooper House off of Washington Street. It is a safe place of community, fellowship, worship, and service. We strive to grow stronger in our faith, and stronger together.
95654.description_html: UKirk means "University Church" and is a name that Presbyterian (PCUSA) Campus Ministries are adopting all across the country. We aspire to be faithful to God, to love others as Christ loves us, and to trust the leading of the Holy Spirit in our life together. The mission of UKirk at Virginia Tech is to nurture an inclusive faith community, respond to human needs, and promote peace and justice as Christ teaches us. UKirk is a safe place to explore what you believe and deepen your faith as you connect with other students. We are a progressive faith community on campus, and we celebrate our LGBTQ+ students, affirming the fullness of who they are. All are welcome!

74597.name: Ultimate Club at Virginia Tech
74597.summary: A team that shares a common goal of competing at the most competitive Ultimate Frisbee tournaments on the East Coast. In order to remain a competitive team in the region, we practice 3-4 times a week and attend 3-4 tournaments a semester.
74597.description_html:
The Ultimate Club At Virginia Tech encompasses two competitive teams. The Club has an A-team and a B-team. Tryouts for the A-team are still TBA. Players that do not make A-team are more than welcome and encouraged to play with the B-team. A-team and B-team are very similar in the fact that they both practice at least two times a week and travel anywhere between 2-5 tournaments a semester. However, they differ in the level of competition. The fall semester serves as a learning curve for most of the team with tournaments that get players used to college ultimate.

The spring serves as the official season of USA ultimate, here is when game scores matter and the rankings of teams are calculated. There is a regular season which starts immediately upon return from winter break and concludes usually in early April. Upon conclusion of the regular season, playoffs begin. Playoffs consist of three tournaments: Sectionals, Regionals, & Nationals. Sectionals includes all of Virginia-Based Teams. Regionals includes all of Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina, Delaware, Maryland, and D.C. Lastly, Nationals is comprised of the top 20 teams across America. Typically the 6 top teams from the Virginia Section go to play at the Atlantic Coast Regional Tournament. From there only the top 2 or 3 teams move onto to play in the final leg of the championship series: Nationals.

71468.name: Undergraduate Biomedical Engineering Society
71468.summary: UBES and its members encourage the development and utilization of knowledge in the biomedical engineering field, we enhance interaction within the scientific community.
71468.description_html: The objective of UBES is to provide guidance to those students on how to get involved with biomedical engineering-related activities on the Virginia Tech campus. We work directly with biomedical engineering students of all grade levels to increase participation in outreach projects, research collaboration, and social events. Students are encouraged to be a biomedical engineering major or minor, but this is not required for membership.

327215.name: Undergraduate Public Health Association at Virginia Tech
327215.summary: We are undergraduate students raising awareness and promoting professionalism in Public Health.
327215.description_html: UPHA is a student led organization for undergraduates who care about public health and want to make a difference. We bring students together to learn, grow, and take action. Whether that’s raising awareness about important health issues, building professional skills, or giving back to our community.

69711.name: Undergraduate Student Representative to the Board of Visitors
69711.summary: The Undergraduate Representatives to the BOV serve as a liaison between the Board and the students. The representative informs the undergraduate constituency of matters affecting them and solicit ideas, information, concerns and feedback from them.
69711.description_html:
The Virginia Tech Board of Visitors is the governing body of the university. It is composted of 14 members, 13 of whom are appointed by the governor, and the 14th member is the president of the Board of Agriculture and Consumer Services, who serves ex-officio. The term of office for each member is four years.

Student representatives to the BOV serve as liaisons between the board and the students. The undergraduate student representative to the Board of Visitors is selected annually by the board through a competitive process to provide a two-way channel of communication between the Board and the undergraduate student body.  The undergraduate representative is expected to attend all Board meetings and participate in other university committees, events, and activities as requested by virtue of their position to represent the undergraduate perspective.  In order to do so, the representative employs various methods of communication to inform the undergraduate constituency of matters affecting them and to solicit ideas, information, concerns and feedback from them.

341801.name: Undergraduate Student Senate at Virginia Tech
341801.summary: As part of shared governance at Virginia Tech, USS representatives (President, VPs, Senators, and Directors) work to understand and advocate for the needs of their constituencies and improve the undergraduate student experience at Virginia Tech.
341801.description_html:
Mission

Through servant leadership, meaningful advocacy, and the empowerment of the undergraduate student body, the Undergraduate Student Senate (USS) delivers a higher quality of life and inclusive representation for every Hokie.

Vision Statement

To be the national leader for collegiate student governance through impactful legislation, collaborative advocacy, and exemplary character.

Core Values

Approachability, Accessibility, Representation, Stewardship, Integrity

 

For more information about the USS and involvement opportunities, please visit our website and follow us on our social media!

408751.name: Undergraduate Students for Hospice Volunteering @Virginia Tech
408751.summary: USHV @ Virginia Tech strives to service hospice patients in the New River Valley region by partnering with Medi Hospice to connect students with patients and to raise awareness about hospice and palliative care through campus-wide events.
408751.description_html: USHV @ Virginia Tech strives to service hospice patients in the New River Valley region by partnering with Medi Hospice to connect students with patients, host in-person training sessions, make blankets, cards, and kits for patients and caregivers, and raise awareness about the importance of hospice and palliative care through campus-wide events.

69128.name: UNICEF Club at Virginia Tech
69128.summary: UNICEF is a non-profit organization that works to deliver the essentials that give our most vulnerable population, children, an equitable chance in life: health care, safe water, nutrition, education, emergency relief, and more.
69128.description_html: The United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund’s (UNICEF) mission is centered around providing the fundamental necessities such as health care, clean water and sanitation, nutrition, education, emergency support, and additional services to children in disadvantaged circumstances. UNICEF currently operates in 190 countries and territories, delivering vital supplies and assistance to children who are in urgent need. The UNICEF Club at Virginia Tech will aid UNICEF with its mission by mobilizing students to educate, fundraise, advocate, and volunteer regarding children’s rights starting in our local community and expanding further out.

420476.name: United Against Inequities in Disease at Virginia Tech
420476.summary: Chapter of the national nonprofit, United Against Inequities in Disease, at Virginia Tech
420476.description_html: UAID is a national organization that seeks to use research and interdisciplinary approaches with local partners to create sustainable changes in the community in relation to public health. We also would like to host events on campus to raise awareness about public health issues to students, as well as implement projects that will promote the wellbeing of the community in which our campus resides.

69708.name: United Council of Fraternities and Sororities
69708.summary: The United Council of Fraternities and Sororities strives to provide an inclusive Greek community through advocating for intercultural exchange by fostering the development of scholarship, leadership, and membership in the spirit of Ut Prosim.
69708.description_html: The United Council of Fraternities and Sororities strives to provide an inclusive Greek community through advocating for intercultural exchange by fostering the development of scholarship, leadership, and membership in the spirit of Ut Prosim. The United Council of Fraternities and Sororities aims to harmonize the diverse organizations by accurately representing and embodying the values that uniquely define constituent organizations.

71283.name: United Feminist Movement
71283.summary: United Feminist Movement is an organization centered around intersectional feminism that believes in equity for underrepresented communities and identities. UFM advocates for social justice issues through education, activism, and community outreach.
71283.description_html:
United Feminist Movement is an organization centered around intersectional feminism that believes in equity for all marginalized communities and identities. UFM works on social justice issues through education, activism, and community outreach. We are a group of people from an array of backgrounds and all are welcome at our meetings.

Meeting times: Wednesdays on Campus - follow our Instagram @ufm.vt for Updates

To learn more about our club and our actions, feel free to attend our meetings or contact leadership at the following emails:

Operations Director: Ali Raia (ali23@vt.edu)
Financial Director: Maya Noueihed (mayand09@vt.edu)
Marketing Director: Bella Seoane (aseoane05@vt.edu)
Development Director: Anissa Burgard (banissa23@vt.edu)

344665.name: Universities Allied for Essential Medicine
344665.summary: A global network of university students who believe that our universities have an opportunity and a responsibility to improve global access to public health and life-saving medicines by affecting public research.
344665.description_html:
Our Mission is simple but powerful: we work to promote access to medicines and medical innovations, change norms and practices in academic patenting and licensing, and empower students to advocate for a biomedical R&D system that works for everyone. Guided by principles of non-partisanship, democracy, transparency, solidarity, and respect, we are a non-profit organization driven by the passion and commitment of our members.

As students from all over the world, we stand united in our belief that access to medicines is a fundamental human right. Universities have a social contract with society, and as educational and research institutions, they have a responsibility to promote and manage the deployment of innovations for the public benefit. With our members' intellectual sophistication, rigor, and integrity, we will fight for increased innovation and access to medicines and health-related technologies for all.

369996.name: Uno Club at Virginia Tech
369996.summary: We meet every week an play Uno at 6:30! Our goal is to create a fun & friendly environment for any and all Virginia Tech Students. Join our GroupMe (posted below) or send an email for info on meetings!
369996.description_html: We meet up and play Uno every Tuesday at 6:30! Our main goal is to provide students with an chance to socialize and get engaged with the community through the hit Mattel title, Uno. Absolutely no club dues or minimum attendance requirements! Feel free to join the club Groupme for updates and meeting info! https://groupme.com/join_group/91927171/jaWn4zTD

105908.name: US Coast Guard Auxiliary University Program at Virginia Tech
105908.summary: The US Coast Guard Auxiliary University Program (AUP) at Virginia Tech seeks to develop well-rounded and experienced future military officer candidates and government leaders while supporting the Coast Guard Auxiliary's critical missions.
105908.description_html:
- Through its relationship with the U.S. Coast Guard Auxiliary New River Valley Flotilla (83) and the Virginia Tech Corps of Cadets, AUP at Virginia Tech seeks to develop well-rounded and experienced future military officer candidates and government leaders while supporting the Coast Guard Auxiliary's critical missions.

- AUP at Virginia Tech provides its members with countless opportunities in areas such as recreational boating safety (RBS), sea and air operations, marine safety and environmental protection, communications, public affairs, public education, and more!

- Many of the students in AUP at Virginia Tech are cadets, however, we highly encourage civilians interested in learning about military service, seamanship, volunteering, or leadership to inquire about joining the Coast Guard Auxiliary.

- Many of our students are also looking to commission as officers in the military, generally through the Coast Guard. Because Virginia Tech is a Senior Military College (SMC), cadets who wish to pursue a commission in the Coast Guard get exclusive access to apply for the USCG Direct Commission Selected School (DCSS) program which reduces initial officer training from 12 weeks to 5 weeks! Participation in AUP also provides significant benefits when applying for these officer programs as it puts you well above other applicants without this experience.

- Not all students plan to commission, and we are still committed to assisting all of our students in finding private or public sector jobs that they are passionate about.

- Another unique benefit of the Coast Guard Auxiliary University Program is access to amazing internships with active duty Coast Guard units! You could spend your summer doing boat operations at a small boat station, learning search and rescue (SAR) operations at a Sector headquarters, getting to fly in helicopters at an Air Station, or being out on the ocean on a cutter. The opportunities are endless and are only available through the Coast Guard Auxiliary University Program.

74197.name: USITT Student Chapter - Virginia Tech
74197.summary: USITT is a student group focused on supporting the development of theatrical technicians and designers. The group is associated with the national technical theater organization USITT, United States Institute for Theatre Technology.
74197.description_html:
The efforts of our USITT Student Chapter are threefold: Fundraising, Education, and Outreach. As a member, you'll get to partake in a number of unique opportunities to learn more about the field of technical theatre. Members are also eligible to receive conference funding as a result of fundraising efforts we do throughout the semester.

If you're interested in joining, don't hesitate to reach out! We'd love to welcome you to our chapter!

125653.name: Valiant Indoor Guard at Virginia Tech
125653.summary: Indoor guard is a competitive, performance-based activity that includes dance, flag, rifle, and sabre techniques used in routines that make up a show and performed at several competitions across Virginia and North Carolina throughout the spring semester.
125653.description_html:
Valiant is a student-run, competitive winter guard (indoor color guard) in which members will practice their dance and equipment skills/techniques to create a unified performance. Valiant aims to facilitate personal and performance-related growth in its members, and members should be challenged accordingly. 

This group aims to entertain while representing Virginia Tech through high-level competition and artistic expression.

391592.name: Valorant at Virginia Tech
391592.summary: Valorant at Virginia Tech aspires to bring together students who are interested and passionate about Valorant, in developing a club with a strong sense of community. Furthermore, we aim to provide a casual and competitive experience for all members.
391592.description_html:
About us:
Valorant at Virginia Tech aspires to bring together students who are interested and passionate about Valorant, in developing a club with a strong sense of community. Furthermore, Valorant at Virginia Tech aims to develop the interpersonal and strategic life skills of all our members in and out of the game, combat gaming stigmas to ensure the inclusivity of marginalized and diverse backgrounds, provide opportunities for students seeking experience and networks in the esports field, and compete at the highest level within Valorant collegiate competition.

General Body Meetings:
We host monthly general body meetings that offer food, games and information regarding competitive events and casual events including potlucks, pizza and quick weekend competitions.

Collegiate Competition:
Anyone is welcome to try out, just know that the competition for making a spot on the roster is extremely fierce and no spot is guaranteed!

Come join our discord server if you're interested! The Discord server is where we will be actively posting information about upcoming events and meetings we host throughout the semester!

414680.name: Vascular Surgery Interest Group
414680.summary: The Vascular Surgery Interest Group (VSIG) is a student-led organization dedicated to fostering interest in vascular surgery among medical students. Our mission is to provide exposure to the specialty through hands-on workshops, mentorship, and education
414680.description_html: Mission Statement: The mission of the Vascular Surgery Interest Group (VSIG) is to foster medical student interest in vascular surgery through education, hands-on experiences, mentorship, and research opportunities. Our goal is to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of the specialty by exploring both open and endovascular surgical techniques, the management of vascular diseases, and the role of vascular surgeons in modern healthcare. Purpose: The Vascular Surgery Interest Group (VSIG) serves as a platform for medical students to engage with the field of vascular surgery through interactive workshops, clinical experiences, and professional networking. We collaborate with faculty, residents, and practicing vascular surgeons to offer suturing and anastomosis labs, ultrasound and Doppler training, case discussions, and procedural simulations. Additionally, our organization provides students with mentorship and career guidance on vascular surgery training pathways, including the integrated and independent residency tracks. Through panel discussions, research opportunities, and residency application workshops, we aim to support students at every stage of their career exploration. Beyond technical skills, VSIG encourages collaboration, leadership, and innovation in the field of vascular surgery. We seek to inspire the next generation of vascular surgeons by fostering a community of learning, curiosity, and professional development. Whether you are set on pursuing vascular surgery or simply exploring surgical subspecialties, VSIG welcomes all students interested in expanding their knowledge and gaining hands-on experience in this dynamic and evolving field.

349702.name: Vawter Hall Community
349702.summary: Residents and Friends of Vawter Hall

62508.name: Venture Out Outdoor Center
62508.summary: Venture Out is a student service within Recreational Sports that provides fun, safe, and educational outdoor services to the students, faculty, staff, and community of Blacksburg.
62508.description_html:
The Venture Out Center specializes in exciting outdoor adventures, quality rental gear at unbeatable rates, and valuable resources to help you plan the perfect adventure.

Venture Out offers extensive outdoor resources on local, regional, and national recreation opportunities. We have a variety of brochures and books on hiking, backpacking, and camping in the New River Valley including information on all of the Virginia State Parks and National Forest. Venture Out’s knowledgeable staff can provide you with personal advice to help you with your next adventure. Let Venture Out be your link to the outdoors! Call or visit us today at 205 W Roanoke St.

70380.name: Veterans@Virginia Tech
70380.summary: Military-connected organization that aims to aid the transition of veterans and reservists from their time in service to civilian and student life. Veterans@VT is open to all student veterans, reservists, drillist, and dependents.
70380.description_html:
Veterans@VT is a military-connected organization that aims to aid the transition of veterans and reservists from their time in service to civilian and student life. Veterans@VT is open to all student veterans, reservists, drillist, and dependents. We are a registered student organization (RSO) and an active chapter member of the Student Veterans of America. We are a diverse and vibrant student group comprised of members from every branch of the military and other military-connected students. 

Our primary goal is to connect military-connected members, providing a safe community for all military-connected personnel. We do this by holding regular events, ranging from laser tag and football tailgates to brewery tours and hikes. We also aim to better support members in their academic studies by providing a private study lounge called the VetZone in Johnston Student Center. In the VetZone, we have a free printer, Keurig, mini refrigerator, microwave, TV, and lounge area. We encourage veterans and dependents to access this room whenever Johnston Student Center is open and bring other students in to relax and study with.

Our organization continues to evolve and would like any veterans to join and influence the direction in which we can help shape the success of our country's veterans.

72220.name: Veterinarians as One Inclusive Community for Empowerment at the Virginia-Maryland Regional College of Veterinary Medicine
72220.summary: VOICE seeks to increase awareness, respect, and sensitivity to differences among all individuals and communities in the field of veterinary medicine. VOICE also aims to celebrate diversity within our profession.
72220.description_html:
Veterinarians as One for an Inclusive Community for Empowerment (VOICE)

VOICE is a student-run organization that seeks to increase awareness, respect, and sensitivity to differences among all individuals and communities in the field of veterinary medicine. VOICE also aims to celebrate diversity within our profession, to encourage campus environments that embrace diversity and promote the success of all students, and to emphasize the importance of cross-cultural awareness in veterinary medicine in order to meet the needs of our diversifying clientele.

Members accomplish this through hosting events such as heritage month celebrations, guest lectures, and service events. 

Our mission at VMCVM VOICE:

  • To celebrate cultural and ethnic diversity in the veterinary community
  • To promote a culture of tolerance and awareness
  • To provide education and outreach
  • To address sociocultural issues within the profession and our communities

VMCVM VOICE hosts events throughout the semester including speakers, salsa nights, international food potlucks, BBQs, movie nights, and service events.

137450.name: Veterinary Business Management Association
137450.summary: The VBMA is a student driven organization dedicated to advancing the profession through: •Increasing business knowledge •Creating networking opportunities •Empowering students to achieve their personal and professional goals
137450.description_html:
Our Mission

     The VBMA, Veterinary Business Management Association is a national student driven organization dedicated to advancing the profession through increasing business knowledge, creating networking opportunities, and empowering students to achieve their personal and professional goals.

     The Business Certificate is the culmination of the lessons taught through the VBMA curriculum, and is a tangible representation of the knowledge ascertained by VBMA members through their time in the program. Comprising either 16 (Business Certificate) or 32 (Business Certificate with Honors) hours of educational credit, completion of the Business Certificate develops the business knowledge of each student and readies them for a productive career in veterinary medicine as a successful associate or business owner.

     Through interactive lectures, workshops, and events outside of the rigorous veterinary school curriculum, the Business Certificate graduate is aware and knowledgeable about the concepts of  business and personal finance, management, emotional intelligence, marketing, and more. The Business Certificate is founded on the following four pillars:

  • Category 1: BUSINESS FINANCE
  • Category 2: BUSINESS OPERATIONS, MANAGEMENT, OWNERSHIP
  • Category 3: BUSINESS LEADERSHIP SKILLS
  • Category 4: CAREER AND PERSONAL DEVELOPMENT

177481.name: Veterinary Imaging Club at the Virginia-Maryland College of Veterinary Medicine
177481.summary: To foster veterinary student engagement and interest in the field of radiology and provide opportunities for experience with different imaging modalities.
177481.description_html: This is an organization made in order to create opportunities for veterinary students to have increased access to veterinary imaging modalities, as well as practice reading those same modalities.

357879.name: VIA
357879.summary:
Explore. Discover. Decide.
What do you want to do with your life? At VIA, we love that question. That’s because we’re a community of explorers committed to finding our passion in school and designing our path afterward.
357879.description_html:
In the VIA Living-Learning Community, we offer students from any major (or no major at all!) the space, structure, and skills to discover what really sparks passion for you. In VIA you’ll get all the space, support, and structure you need to identify or declare a major, define your career ambitions, and make a solid plan to achieve your goals.

 

Who VIA is for?

VIA is open any student who’s deciding on a major. That includes University Studies students, undecided majors within each college, or declared majors who want to explore their options.

 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BtTFrT-ncls

374021.name: VIA Alumni Network
374021.summary: The VIA Alumni Network is a way for former VIA students to stay involved with the VIA community and provide resources and guidance to current VIA students in their major selection journey.
374021.description_html: VIA is a Living Learning Community created for all freshmen with any level of uncertainty toward their major and/or career path. In 2023, the VIA Alumni Network was founded as an extension of this LLC. While VIA alone helps approximately 75% of its members select a major by their second semester, the VAN aims to increase this rate even higher by fostering connections between former and present VIA members. The VAN is an entirely student-led organization that's here to provide additional resources and exposure to the freshmen and guide them as needed on their journey to success.

69400.name: Vietnamese Community at Virginia Tech
69400.summary: Vietnamese students and scholars, Vietnamese language speakers, and friends surrounding Blacksburg.
69400.description_html:
Viet Tech is dedicated to enriching the experiences of Vietnamese students at Virginia Tech by fostering a supportive community that facilitates lifestyle and cultural integration, academic success, and personal growth in the U.S. Our mission includes sharing experiences, providing assistance with cultural adjustment, preserving Vietnamese cultural values, and promoting cross-cultural understanding.

Viet Tech is open to anyone who is interested in Vietnamese culture. We hope to support you in your academic and cultural journey at Virginia Tech.

Visit our Facebook page at https://www.facebook.com/VTVietnamese

62955.name: Vietnamese Student Association
62955.summary: VSA works to promote the awareness and interest of the Vietnamese culture, its people, and its community. We strive towards promoting Asian/Vietnamese unity within the Hokie Community.
62955.description_html: The purpose of the Vietnamese Student Association is to promote the awareness and interest of the Vietnamese culture, its people, and its community as well as enhancing and furthering pluralism and diversity. Our goal is also to make the Virginia Tech community a place where every member is respected, understood, and has every opportunity to grow, to make Virginia Tech a place where broad inclusiveness is the rule—not the exception. We also promote Vietnamese/Asian Unity in addition to addressing the problems and concerns of the Vietnamese/Asian Community to the Administration and other student organizations at Virginia Tech.

387563.name: Vilasana at VirginiaTech
387563.summary: Vilasana at VT is an Indian classical dance team that offers immersive workshops and performance opportunities to all dancers of all levels to celebrate classical Indian dances like Bharatnatyam, Kuchipudi, Odissi and Kathak.
387563.description_html: The mission for “Vilasana at VT” is to unite Indian classical dancers from diverse backgrounds, fostering a vibrant community dedicated to sharing the deep-rooted traditions of classical Indian dance. Through immersive workshops, we aim to create a platform for sharing and celebrating the multitude of styles within Indian classical dance, including Bharatanatyam, Kuchipudi, Kathak and Odissi. We strive to offer performance opportunities for both beginner and intermediate dancers that not only showcase the talent of individual dancers but also encourage collaboration, idea sharing, growth, and mutual learning for dancers of all backgrounds. Our ultimate goal is to create a vibrant and supportive environment where dancers come together, not only to enhance their skills but also to have fun, forging lasting connections within the classical dance community.

400649.name: Vira Anatolian Dance at Virginia Tech
400649.summary: Vira Anatolian Dance at Virginia Tech celebrates the diverse cultural heritage of Anatolia through dance, offering students opportunities to learn, practice, and perform, fostering inclusivity, cultural awareness, and community engagement.
400649.description_html:
Vira Anatolian Dance at Virginia Tech celebrates the rich cultural heritage of Anatolia through traditional and contemporary dance. Our mission is to promote cultural awareness, inclusivity, and unity within the Virginia Tech community by offering students opportunities to learn, practice, and perform Anatolian dances. We provide a welcoming space for students of all backgrounds to explore Turkish and Anatolian dance forms, fostering cultural appreciation while promoting physical activity, artistic expression, and social connection.


Our dedicated board and enthusiastic members are committed to sharing these traditions with both the Virginia Tech community and the broader New River Valley. Vira Anatolian Dance is proud to offer students a unique cultural experience through dance.

126514.name: Virginia Cooperative Extension-4-H
126514.summary: 4-H is the youth development education program of Virginia Cooperative Extension. 4-H is rich with learning experiences where young people partner with caring adults and volunteers in a fellowship unlike any other program available to youth today.
126514.description_html: 4-H is the youth development education program of Virginia Cooperative Extension. 4-H is rich with learning experiences where young people partner with caring adults and volunteers in a fellowship unlike any other program available to youth today.  Through 4-H, young people are encouraged to participate in a variety of activities that emphasize 4-H's "learning by doing" philosophy of youth development.

71486.name: Virginia Esports Association at Virginia Tech
71486.summary: VESPA caters to a large range of players, from supporting casual community activities to intercollegiate competitive teams. We have monthly meetings with free food and activities. Our supported games are LoL, CS, Valorant, R6S, OW, Dota 2, etc.
71486.description_html:
The Virginia Esports Association (VESPA) supports a variety of activities, such as weekend/semester-long community tournaments, giveaways, watch parties, and intercollegiate teams. Our supported games are League of Legends, Counter-Strike, Valorant, Rainbow Six: Siege, Hero Shooters (Marvel Rivals and Overwatch 2), etc.

 

If you are interested in a game that was not listed above, join our Discord and contact us, we can point you in the right direction or even provide support if you want to start a new game community. Check out our Discord, website, or social media for more information!

 

Membership Checklist:

- Join us on Gobbler Connect

- Join us on Discord

414682.name: Virginia Harm Reduction Student Liaisons and Street Medicine Student Interest Group
414682.summary: A student-led group promoting harm reduction through education, advocacy, and volunteer efforts with Virginia Harm Reduction Coalition.
414682.description_html: Our student-led organization is dedicated to advancing harm reduction and street medicine efforts through education, advocacy, and direct community support. In collaboration with the Virginia Harm Reduction Coalition, we work to reduce the stigma surrounding substance use and promote evidence-based strategies that prioritize health, safety, and dignity. As both a harm reduction and street medicine student interest group, we recognize the intersection of substance use, housing insecurity, and barriers to healthcare. We provide education and training on overdose prevention, naloxone distribution, safer use practices, and other life-saving interventions. By equipping students with the knowledge and skills to engage in compassionate, nonjudgmental care, we prepare future healthcare professionals to serve marginalized populations effectively. Our group actively supports harm reduction and street medicine initiatives by recruiting and organizing volunteers for safer-supply kit building, syringe service programs, and mobile health efforts. Through these initiatives, we not only expand access to vital services but also advocate for policies that promote the well-being of individuals affected by substance use and homelessness. We welcome students from all backgrounds and disciplines who share our commitment to reducing harm and expanding equitable healthcare access. By working together, we aim to create a more informed, compassionate, and supportive environment for all members of our community.

63150.name: Virginia Tech Alpine Ski Team
63150.summary: VT Alpine Ski Team is a co-ed, competitive club sport involving Slalom and GS ski racing. We race in the USCSA Southeast Conference and compete against schools such as UVA, Georgetown, and Duke. Ski experience expected. NO RACING EXPERIENCE REQUIRED!
63150.description_html:
The Virginia Tech Alpine Ski Team has been an active club since 1981. The club is coed and has a men's team and a women's team that compete in the Southeastern Collegiate Ski Conference. There is an A Team, a B Team, and a Practice Team to accommodate all levels of skiers. There is no racing experience required but ski experience is expected.

The ski team participates in dry-land training from late September until December. These practices consist of sports, cardio/weight workouts, and team bonding activities(hiking, kayaking, etc.)

The team hosts a week long pre-season camp during winter break at Jay Peak Resort in Jay, VT. On-snow practices begin at Winterplace Ski Resort, in Beckley, WV during the second semester. The team competes in Slalom and Giant Slalom events throughout the months of January and February at various locations in West Virginia, Virginia, North Carolina, and Pennsylvania.

The goal of the VT Alpine Ski Team is to provide students with the opportunity to compete in ski racing and provide a structured path to becoming a better skier. It's also a fun and affordable way to meet new people from VT while doing something you love.

For more information, check out our website or follow us on Instagram:

*WEBSITE*

*VT Alpine Ski Instagram*

140539.name: Virginia Tech Alumni Association
140539.summary: The Virginia Tech Alumni Association (VTAA) keeps the Hokie Nation connected “for life” through Networking, Services, and Involvement.  VTAA supports students through student programs, alumni chapter scholarships, and senior transition programs.

420948.name: Virginia Tech Athletics
420948.summary: VT Athletics is committed to excellence, both academically and athletically, and to the personal development of our student-athletes. In the spirit of Ut Prosim, we stand together to serve and represent our university and community.
420948.description_html:
VT Athletics is committed to excellence, both academically and athletically, and to the personal development of our student-athletes. In the spirit of Ut Prosim, we stand together to serve and represent our university and community with integrity and respect.

 

Virginia Tech has competed in varsity sports for more than 100 years. The athletics program was established on September 26, 1891 and the first varsity sporting event was held in the spring of 1892 when the baseball team defeated Newport 18-8.

 

Women’s varsity athletics began in 1976. Currently, Virginia Tech sponsors 22 varsity sports at the NCAA Bowl Championship subdivision level and they are divided equally into 11 men’s sports and 11 women’s sports. The university fields men’s teams in soccer, cross-country, swimming, indoor and outdoor track, football, basketball, wrestling, baseball, golf and tennis. The women’s teams compete in cross-country, golf, volleyball, indoor and outdoor track, swimming, basketball, soccer, tennis, lacrosse and softball.

414684.name: Virginia Tech Carilion Chapter of the Association of Women Surgeons
414684.summary: Mission: to inspire, encourage, and enable women surgeons to realize their professional and personal goals.
414684.description_html: AWS is committed to supporting women surgeons at various stages in their career – from medical school through retirement and offers our members programs and services to: ENGAGE current and future women surgeons to realize their professional and personal goals. EMPOWER women to succeed. EXCEL in those aspirations through mentorship, education and a networking community that promotes their contributions and achievements as students, surgeons and leaders.

65701.name: Virginia Tech Clay Target Team
65701.summary: Our main focus is to educate collegiate students about the various disciplines of clay target shooting as a sport in a comfortable and safe environment. Also, we attend national competitions throughout the year against other highly competitive schools.
65701.description_html:
The members of the Virginia Tech Clay Target Team compete in a number of different collegiate and NSCA events during both the Fall and Spring semesters.  These include, but are not limited to; Skeet, Trap, International Skeet, Olympic Trap, 5-stand, FITASC, Sporting Clays, and Super Sporting.

The team hosts many events throughout the year and also travels to several competitions in Virginia as well as competitions in Kentucky, Tennessee, Delaware, Maryland, New Jersey, Florida, Georgia, and the ACUI Collegiate National Clay Target Championships in San Antonio, Texas.

The team practices on a weekly basis at the Izaak Walton Club in Christiansburg, and holds additional practices at Fun Gun Shooting Range in Pulaski, Virginia.

The Virginia Tech Clay Target Team strives for excellence in citizenship, scholarship, and marksmanship.  The club sport is open to all students, graduate or undergraduate, who would like to improve their clay target shooting abilities. There is no experience required, as we want to open up this sport to people who are ready to learn about gun safety and how fun competitions can be!

96132.name: Virginia Tech Club Baseball
96132.summary: The Virginia Tech Club Baseball team is affiliated with the Rec Sports program at Virginia Tech. As a member of the National Club Baseball Association, the Hokies compete in the Mid Atlantic North Conference.
96132.description_html: The club baseball team here at Virginia Tech is completely student run, meaning that we do not have a coach. We have a shortened fall schedule, roughly 8 to 10 games, and a full spring schedule, roughly 20 games. We compete within the National Club Baseball Association (NCBA) in the Mid-Atlantic north conference with James Madison University, College of William and Mary, University of Maryland, Longwood University, and the University of Virginia. The top team from each conference goes on to play in the regional tournament, then the winners of those get to compete for the club baseball World Series title. For the past three seasons we have finished at the top of our conference and went on to compete in the regional tournament. During the 2021 and 2023 Spring Season, the Hokies won the regional Championship and in 2021 the NCBA World Series. For us, the baseball is important, but not as important as the friendship. There is a definite emphasis on winning, but at the end of the day we are there because of our shared love of the game and other guys in maroon and orange.

67122.name: Virginia Tech Club Cross Country/Track & Field
67122.summary: The Virginia Tech Club Cross Country/Track & Field team is a student-run organization that brings together athletes of all different skill levels to train in mileage, distance, sprint, and field event workouts, and compete together. No tryouts necessary!
67122.description_html: The Virginia Tech Club Cross Country/Track & Field Team provides a relaxed and fun environment for athletes of every skill level, while also offering a competitive team feel. There are no tryouts to be on the team, as we want everyone to have the opportunity to run, jump, throw, or sprint, even if they do not have prior experience. We give athletes the chance to continue their cross country or track & field careers while also helping runners find great groups to run with. We practice every weekday, and athletes are offered choices of various distances and paces, with distance, sprint, and field event training. The Club XCTF team encourages every athlete to train at their own level, so workouts and long runs are not required. Members don't have to attend practice every day but are encouraged to attend as much as possible. During the fall semester we travel and compete in cross country meets against other colleges such as UVA and UNC at distances of 5K, 6K, and 8K.  In the spring, we compete with other schools in Track and Field meets. All these races are optional. We put a lot of effort into becoming not only teammates but also friends, so we participate in many fun group activities and social events as a team!

71232.name: Virginia Tech Club Field Hockey
71232.summary: Virginia Tech Field Hockey is comprised of dedicated athletes who compete against varsity & other club teams. VTFH prides itself in unity both on & off the field. The club welcomes anyone who enjoys playing and is looking for fun & competitive recreation
71232.description_html:
Virginia Tech Club Field Hockey began as an answer to the removal of the intercollegiate team.  Over the years, the amount of people and competition has increased substantially upholding the competitive nature of the game. Team members bond both on and off the field, further expanding their love for field hockey.

Tryouts are held every fall. The fall season lasts from late August through the middle of November. We travel to several schools, play other club and varsity teams, and take part in as many games and tournaments as possible. We strive to do our best during the season in order to qualify for the National Tournament.

During the spring, we will have a shortened season to accommodate the weather and to continue practicing. Although the fall is our main season, we usually still attend 2-3 tournaments in the spring including the Spring National Tournament.

69040.name: Virginia Tech Club Golf
69040.summary: The purpose of the Golf Club of Virginia Tech is to provide students an opportunity to play competitive golf in college while maintaining their current academic studies and social life.
69040.description_html: The Golf Club of Virginia Tech is an avenue for students to play competitive golf in a team atmosphere. The Golf Club of Virginia Tech takes pride in competing against the best schools in the nation and strives for a national championship every year. Along with the competitive atmosphere there is an ample amount of camaraderie in tournaments and sportsmanship out of respect for the game of golf. This is an organization for anyone interested in the game of golf and includes a wide range of skill levels.

67852.name: Virginia Tech Club Ice Hockey Team
67852.summary: The Virginia Tech Club Ice Hockey team was formed in 1984 as a local men's league team based out of Roanoke.  Since then, our team's success has continued to grow with the dedication our players have demonstrated to the program, and to each other.
67852.description_html:
The Virginia Tech Hokies hockey team was formed in the fall of 1984 as a local men’s league team based out of the LancerLot ice arena in Vinton, Virginia, just outside of Roanoke. At the time, the university provided a $500 stipend and granted permission to use the Virginia Tech logo on the uniforms.

The Hokies played their first full intercollegiate schedule in the 1985 season after being accepted into the Southern Collegiate Hockey Association (SCHA), which included thirteen other member schools split into two divisions:

  • Northern Division: Virginia Tech, North Carolina, Duke, North Carolina State, Liberty, Old Dominion, and George Mason.

  • Southern Division: Florida, Georgia, Georgia Tech, Tennessee, Vanderbilt, and Emory.

Because ice time was too expensive, practices were often held on dry land or on local ponds when they froze. The Hokies’ first full season ended with a 6-8-2 record, which was considered a success as it laid the foundation for the future.

ACHA Formation and Facility Challenges (1991–1995)

In 1991, the American Collegiate Hockey Association (ACHA) was formed as the national governing body for collegiate club-level ice hockey in the United States. Teams were split into Division I, II, or III, with the Hokies and the SCHA joining Division II.

In the spring of 1993, a massive snowstorm caused the structural collapse of the Hokies’ home arena, putting the team’s future in jeopardy. Fortunately, that summer the Roanoke Civic Center was upgraded into a full-time ice arena—part of an effort to attract an ECHL team—and became the Hokies’ new home for years to come.

In 1995, the Northern Division teams of the SCHA broke off to form the Atlantic Coast Collegiate Hockey League (ACCHL), which included Virginia Tech, North Carolina, Duke, North Carolina State, Liberty, Old Dominion, and newcomers Virginia and Virginia Commonwealth. The Hokies thrived in the ACCHL’s inaugural season, posting a 13-1 record and capturing their first league championship.

Championship Runs and League Transition (2009–2011)

In 2009, the Hokies went undefeated in ACCHL play (9-0) and captured another league championship, finishing the season 18-6-1.

In 2010, they repeated as ACCHL champions with a 6-1 league record, ultimately finishing the year 15-4-3.

That summer, the program moved to the tougher Mid-Atlantic Collegiate Hockey Association (MACHA) with the goal of competing at a higher regional and national level. In their first MACHA season (2010-11), the Hokies earned their highest-ever Southeast regional ranking (#4) and won the inaugural MACHA South Championship by defeating Liberty 4-3 in the title game—making it three straight championships across leagues.

The Hokies finished the 2010-11 season ranked #6 in the Southeast and advanced to the ACHA Southeast Regional Tournament, where they fell 2-1 to Penn State, ending the season with a 19-12-2 record.

National Tournament Breakthrough (2011–2013)

The MACHA later changed its abbreviation to MACH to avoid confusion with another league, while keeping its North and South divisions.

In 2011-12, the Hokies entered the ACHA Southeast Regional Tournament as the #7 seed. After defeating Kennesaw State 7-5, they upset Liberty 5-3 to advance to their first-ever ACHA National Tournament in Ft. Myers, Florida, finishing the season ranked #12 in the nation out of nearly 180 Division II programs.

The following season, the Hokies finished third in the MACH South during the regular season but went on a remarkable playoff run, defeating Liberty, UMBC, and Penn State to capture their first combined MACH Championship. They reached the Southeast Regional semifinals before falling to Bowling Green, narrowly missing a return trip to Nationals.

Return to ACCHL and Recent Success (2018–2023)

The Hokies returned to their original home rink, the LancerLot, and rejoined the ACCHL starting in the 2018 season.

In 2021-22, they won the ACCHL regular-season championship before falling in the semifinals of the playoff tournament.

Modern Era Milestones (2024–Present)

  • January 4, 2025: The Hokies played and won their first-ever outdoor game, shutting out UNC 6-0 at Truist Field in Charlotte.

  • 2024-25 Season: Finished with a 24-4-1 overall record, one of the most successful seasons in program history.

  • Coaching Achievement: Head Coach Joey Mullen, in his 15th season, surpassed 200 career wins, becoming the winningest coach in both Virginia Tech hockey and ACCHL history.

  • Postseason: Returned to the Southeast Regional Tournament for the first time in five years, falling in double overtime to Ohio in the first round.

Once again, the Hokies look to continue their winning ways heading into the 2025-26 season. Stay tuned for more updates as the program continues to build on its proud tradition.

69046.name: Virginia Tech Competitive Cheerleading
69046.summary: Virginia Tech Competitive Cheerleading is a club sports team that represents Virginia Tech in 3-5 cheerleading competitions during the year.
69046.description_html: The Virginia Tech Competitive Cheer team is made up of 20-25 athletes.  Our team has been all-girl as well as coed in the past.  Male and female students are encouraged to try-out, however the division of our team depends on demand.  We compete every year at NCA College Nationals in Daytona Beach, Florida along with other competitions along the east coast.  We also practice 2-3 nights a week.  Our team is strictly a competition team and we DO NOT perform at Virginia Tech varsity athletic events.

88024.name: Virginia Tech Corps of Cadets
88024.summary: A significant part of the university since its establishment in 1872, the Corps of Cadets has evolved into a world-class leader-development program that still understands that great leaders require great character.
88024.description_html: Our mission is to graduate leaders of exemplary character who are instilled with the values and skills essential for leadership success in service to our nation. Since 1872, the Corps of Cadets has produced outstanding leaders for the commonwealth and the nation. Seven of our alumni have earned the Medal of Honor, and more than 100 of our graduates have been promoted to general and flag officer ranks. Countless alumni have achieved success in business, industry, and public service.

160047.name: Virginia Tech Corps of Cadets Regiment
160047.summary: The Virginia Tech Corps of Cadets trains leaders by creating a regimented and disciplined environment that educates and develops the whole person – mentally, morally, and physically.
160047.description_html:
As one of the nation's six Senior Military Colleges, the Virginia Tech Corps of Cadets trains leaders by creating a regimented and disciplined environment that educates and develops the whole person – mentally, morally, and physically. 

At the conclusion of a successful cadet’s career in the Corps, he or she will have accepted the following ideals as core values of character and will be prepared to both embody these ideals personally and pass them on to others:

Personal Integrity: A cadet adheres to the highest standards of personal and moral conduct. The foundation for the development of personal integrity is the Cadet Honor Code: “A cadet will not lie, cheat, or steal, nor tolerate those who do.”

Professional Competence: Cadets continuously strive to master the requirements and competencies of their chosen profession. This begins with knowledge of adherence to and enforcement of Corps regulations, policies and philosophies. It continues with the dedication and desire to master all elements related to their specific military service or chosen civilian profession.

Respect: A cadet treats every individual with dignity and respect, and accepts every individual as a valuable and contributing member of the organization.

65099.name: Virginia Tech Crew Team
65099.summary: The Virginia Tech Rowing Club is a club sport, run by students through the Virginia Tech Recreational Sports Department. Comprised of both Men's/Women's Varsity and Novice teams, traveling to compete with other Club & NCAA Division teams.
65099.description_html: The Virginia Tech Rowing Club is a club sport, run by students through the Virginia Tech Recreational Sports Department. Comprised of both Men's/Women's Varsity and Novice teams, traveling to compete with other Club and NCAA Division teams up and down the east coast. Practices are daily and are either at Claytor Lake or at the fieldhouse on campus.

71236.name: Virginia Tech Cricket Club
71236.summary: VT Cricket represents an international sport followed by at least a billion people worldwide. Everyone is welcome to play however the best 11 get to compete in regional (Mid Atlantic Cricket Conference) and national tournaments. Follow us on Instagram.
71236.description_html: The Club is the university's official cricket franchise. We have members in numbers and diversity. The club holds practice sessions on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays at 927 Tech Center Drive, Blacksburg, Virginia 24060. Follow our Instagram page since it is very active, and our officers will promptly help any interested party. We play an annual season in a local conference chapter of North American cricket called the Mid Atlantic Cricket Conference against teams from Virginia. Moreover, we compete nationally against other collegiate cricket teams including but not exclusively ACC in tournaments organized by North American cricket organizations. VTCC supports anyone to come and play cricket especially those who are not familiar with the sport.

69133.name: Virginia Tech Cycling Club
69133.summary: The VT Cycling Team is a group of cyclists who participate in rides, races, and other cycling events within the Atlantic Coast Cycling Conference.  All are welcome to join regardless of skill.  We compete in Road, Track, Mountain, and Cyclocross events.
69133.description_html: The Virginia Tech Cycling Team is open to all bicyclists, regardless of age, gender, discipline, or ability. Everyone is encouraged to join as a means of improving their cycling skills, overall fitness, enjoyment of the outdoors, and to meet other cyclists. The club supports a road cycling team, mountain bike cycling team, track cycling team, and cyclocross cycling team in Atlantic Collegiate Cycling Conference races as well as designated out-of-conference races and national competitions.

70251.name: Virginia Tech Equestrian Club
70251.summary: The club provides a forum for conversation about horses and their care, as well as allows students to organize, participate in, and observe equine related events. The club also sponsors the three VT Intercollegiate Riding Teams in their competitions
70251.description_html: The Virginia Tech Equestrian Club is a recognized club in the Virginia Tech Sports Club Federation. We welcome all horse enthusiasts, regardless of experience with horses or major. The club strives to provide a forum for conversation about horses and their care, as well as allow students to organize, participate in, and observe equine related events such as horse shows and clinics. Guest speakers are often invited to join our meetings, and the club frequently makes trips off campus to participate in social and fundraising activities. The Club is responsible for supporting and sponsoring the three VT Intercollegiate Riding Teams in their competitive riding schedule during the academic school year.

65793.name: Virginia Tech Fencing Club
65793.summary: The Virginia Tech Fencing Club strives to ensure that the Olympic sport of fencing is available to anyone who wishes to join our community. We welcome all of varying expertise and offer free beginner lessons for those who want to learn.
65793.description_html:
Practices are on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday from 8:00-10:30 pm during the school year.

If you are interested in joining the club, whether you have fenced for years or never at all, please send an email to keegs3141@vt.edu and simply show up to practice where one of our officers will accommodate you as necessary. All equipment is provided by the club so you do not need to purchase your own before coming to practice (please do NOT show up in jeans or shorts, leggings or sweatpants are highly recommended!).

The Virginia Tech Fencing Club (VTFC) is a student-run Recreational Sports Club that was established in 1972. Our purpose is to promote the international sport of fencing. VTFC members may be anyone at Virginia Tech, including enrolled students, faculty, and staff. We aim to support anyone who wants to fence recreationally or competitively, whether they are just starting or have fenced for years. 

As a competitive club we field both men's and women's teams in all three Olympic weapons (epee, foil, and saber) in collegiate club events and United States Fencing Association (USFA) individual competitions. We subsidize and encourage all our fencers to compete in the competitions we attend. Newcomers are always welcome!

69907.name: Virginia Tech Gymnastics Club
69907.summary: Club gymnastics practices in Christiansburg at Virginia Techniques and travels to other universities to compete. Club gymnastics accepts all skill and participation levels.
69907.description_html:
The Virginia Tech Gymnastics Club consists of men and women of all skill levels: whether you are new to gymnastics or a veteran of the sport, our gym offers a relaxed learning environment for all. Club members can represent the Hokies on the road competing against other schools or can simply attend the practices for a great workout! We practice at Virginia Techniques Training Center from 8:30-10:30 pm on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Thursdays in Christiansburg. We coordinate rides so everyone can experience this amazing sport!

Each Fall the club hosts its annual Hokie Classic Meet, which usually consists of 10-15 other schools, where members are encouraged to attend. In the spring, they travel to other schools to compete. The club is open to those looking for instruction, competition, and fun.

If you would like to get more information, please contact our president! We look forward to meeting you!

147464.name: Virginia Tech Institute for Creativity, Arts, and Technology
147464.summary: The Institute for Creativity, Arts, and Technology is a university-level research institute positioned at the nexus of the arts, design, engineering and science.  Find ICAT at the Moss Arts Center.
147464.description_html:
A university-level research institute sitting at the nexus of the arts, design, engineering, and science,

the Institute for Creativity, Arts, and Technology is uniquely partnered with the Center for the Arts at

Virginia Tech. By forging a pathway between transdisciplinary research and art, educational innovation,

and scientific and commercial discovery, the institute works to foster the creative process to create new

possibilities for exploration and expression through learning, discovery, and engagement. This includes

preparing students in kindergarten through 12th grade and higher education environments to succeed

in a world that demands teamwork and collaboration of science, technology, engineering, and math

(STEM) disciplines; promoting new research domains that transcend institutionalized boundaries; and

participating with people of all ages in the process of co-creation.

67853.name: Virginia Tech Men's Club Soccer
67853.summary:
Virginia Tech Men's Club Soccer Team is a competitive travel team which competes against other schools across the country. 
For info, visit http://vtclubsoccer.weebly.com/
67853.description_html:
Highly competitive men's soccer team that competes with universities in the area and across the country. In recent years we have reached the semi-finals in both the competitive and open brackets of the NIRSA national club soccer tournament. Check us out on instagram for more information about the team and tryouts @vtclubsoccer

Do not request to connect via Gobbler Connect. If you are interested in trying out for the club team, be on the look out for more information on our instagram page as we approach the upcoming semester.

68923.name: Virginia Tech Men's Club Tennis
68923.summary: We are a competitive tennis team that competes with other collegiate club teams across the nation.
68923.description_html: We are a competitive tennis team that competes with other collegiate club teams across the nation.

84197.name: Virginia Tech Men's Club Water Polo
84197.summary: Men's Club Water Polo Team that represents Virginia Tech in the Collegiate Water Polo Association
84197.description_html: Virginia Tech Men's Club Water Polo competes in fall as part of the Atlantic Conference of the Collegiate Water Polo Association. We also compete in the spring at invitational tournaments. Water polo experience is not required but being a strong swimmer is highly encouraged. All are welcome to come out and try. The top 17 players based on skill will travel to tournaments in the fall.

96301.name: Virginia Tech Men's Lacrosse
96301.summary: The Virginia Tech Men's Lacrosse Team is a competitive team for experienced lacrosse players.  The team travels across the country and plays at the highest level of collegiate club lacrosse.
96301.description_html: Virginia Tech Men's Club Lacrosse is a competitive and dedicated program that provides student-athletes with the opportunity to play high-level lacrosse while balancing their academic commitments. As a self-funded member of the Men's Collegiate Lacrosse Association (MCLA), the team competes against other top collegiate club teams from across the country.

70363.name: Virginia Tech Men's Rugby
70363.summary: Virginia Tech Men's Rugby Football Club
70363.description_html: We are Virginia Tech's rugby team.  Rugby is a brutal full contact sport that requires both strength and fitness.  The season for rugby is both fall and spring: fifteens style is played in the fall and sevens style is played in the spring.  We hold try-outs at the beginning of the fall semester for the fifteen's team.  Fifteens style rugby is much more physical.  Usually, most people who come out will make the team (depending on numbers).  There are two teams: an A side and a B side with 20-25 players per team (which means at most 50 total players).  In past years, we have had a third-C side team if enough players come to tryouts (at least 60 players).  The fifteens season starts in August and ends around mid-November.  Tryouts for the sevens team are held at the beginning of the spring semester.  The sevens team is much more selective: only 15 players will make the team (20 at most).  Sevens style rugby is much more fast-paced and demands a very high fitness level.  The sevens season starts in February and ends in May.

407844.name: Virginia Tech Office of Energy Management
407844.summary: The Virginia Tech Office of Energy Management is a department within the Virginia Tech Division of Facilities in Blacksburg, Virginia. OEM manages campus energy consumption and promotes energy conservation and efficiency throughout Virginia Tech.
407844.description_html: The mission of the Division of Facilities' Office of Energy Management is to guide the operations of the University to achieve tangible reduction in energy consumption on campus through the development and implementation of energy efficiency and management policies, initiatives, and projects.

69055.name: Virginia Tech Rec Sports
69055.summary: Rec Sports at Virginia Tech enriches the Hokie experience through programs, events, and facilities that inspire movement, connection, and well-being for a balanced, energized, and fulfilling life.
69055.description_html:
https://youtu.be/WgsTqEsbbJ0?si=7EZFpGm-WE83myiG

At Virginia Tech Rec Sports, our purpose is to provide exceptional programs, memorable events, and quality facilities that enrich the VT experience—helping Hokies live more energized, balanced, and fulfilled lives.

Our diverse programs invite every Hokie to find their fit and fuel their well-being:

  • Aquatics & Health and Safety – Dive into fitness, skill-building, and certifications that promote lifelong water safety.

  • Fitness – Reach your goals through personal training, group exercise, and opportunities to move with purpose.

  • Golf – Enjoy inclusive recreation and skill development on and off the course.

  • Sport Clubs – Compete, connect, and grow through student-led organizations.

  • Intramural Sports – Play for fun, fitness, and friendship in a variety of team and individual activities.

  • Open Recreation – Make movement part of your day through accessible, drop-in recreation.

  • Special Events – Celebrate community and well-being through experiences that energize and unite Hokies.

  • Venture Out - Venture Out is an excellent way to see beautiful areas, explore, and be active. 

Our facilities include two large indoor recreation centers, a hub facility, and expansive outdoor spaces designed to support every kind of recreation—from high-intensity training to mindful recovery and social connection.

Together, these values shape our commitment to making movement, mindfulness, and community an essential part of every Hokie’s journey.

144815.name: Virginia Tech Recovery Community
144815.summary: The Virginia Tech Recovery Community works to ensure that students do not have to choose between their recovery and their education. We support students who have struggled with addiction (substance and non-substance related) as well as allies!
144815.description_html:
