The Virginia Tech Recovery Community works to ensure that students do not have to choose between their recovery and their education. We support students inside and outside the classroom, organize events and trips, and provide space for recovery meetings. Anyone is welcome to our meetings to find out more. You don’t even have to commit to being sober forever, just sober for today. We happily welcome allies and loved ones seeking information on how to best support others pursuing recovery or battling addiction.

To connect, please email us rc@vt.edu or call 540-231-2233, or or join us at The Roost, 1C Payne Residence Hall.

68666.name: Virginia Tech Rescue Squad
68666.summary: We are the Emergency Medical Services agency proudly serving the campus of Virginia Tech 24/7/365.
68666.description_html: The Virginia Tech Rescue Squad, established in 1969, is the oldest volunteer collegiate rescue squad in the country and the first in the Commonwealth of Virginia. We are a fully student-operated ALS (Advanced Life Support) transport agency that responds to all on-campus medical emergency 911 calls. In addition to emergency response, our members actively staff athletic events, including football games, and teach a variety of basic life support classes, such as CPR, First Aid, REVIVE, Vitals, and Stop the Bleed.

71237.name: Virginia Tech Roller Hockey
71237.summary: The Virginia Tech Roller Hockey team competes in Division III of the SECRHL as a part of the NCRHA. They compete against teams primarily on the east coast and in playoff events at the Regional and National levels.
71237.description_html: We are a competitive roller hockey team playing in the NCRHA.  We look for experienced hockey players that can play at a high level and fast pace.

414686.name: Virginia Tech School of Medicine Family Medicine Interest Group
414686.summary: A student-led group exploring careers in family medicine through mentorship, hands-on experiences, and advocacy for holistic, community-based care.
414686.description_html: The VTCSOM Family Medicine Interest Group (FMIG) is committed to cultivating a passion for comprehensive, patient-centered care among future healthcare providers. We aim to equip medical students with the knowledge, mentorship, and skills necessary to excel in family medicine while introducing students to innovative subspecialties. We hope to empower students to become agents of change within their communities through fostering student leadership and community involvement. Through educational events, outreach, and collaborative learning, we strive to promote continuity of care, preventative health, and holistic well-being for individuals and communities alike.

414687.name: Virginia Tech Science Communication Journal
414687.summary: VT SciCom helps students translate complex science into accessible content while gaining experience in writing, editing, and peer review.
414687.description_html: VT SciCom fosters interest in translating complex science into accessible formats. Our journal provides a platform to submit, refine, and publish scholarly works while gaining experience in peer review, editing, and the publication process.

128254.name: Virginia Tech Services, Inc
128254.summary: Virginia Tech Services, Inc. is an affiliated corporation of Virginia Tech.  The Board of Visitors chartered us in 1968 as an independent, non-profit 501 (c)(3) corporation to operate Virginia Tech's official  on-and off campus bookstores.

60535.name: Virginia Tech Sport Clubs
60535.description_html:
The Sport Club program consists of 29 sport clubs that represent Virginia Tech and the Recreational Sports department at various tournaments and competitions. These clubs are not a part of Virginia Tech's NCAA athletics department, but are competitive by nature. Sport clubs aim to play a crucial role in students' college experience by offering opportunities for students to develop leadership skills, healthy lifestyles, sportsmanship, teamwork and responsibility.

 

To find out more about a sport club, contact the Sport Club Office, or reach out to the club directly using the search feature on GobblerConnect.

135374.name: Virginia Tech Sports Medicine Club
135374.summary: VTSMC aims to further students knowledge of Sports Medicine through case studies, guest speakers, and hands-on in-services.
135374.description_html: VTSMC aims to further students knowledge of Sports Medicine through guest speakers and hands-on in-services. Our social events aim to assist students who are seeking a career in Sports Medicine. Our philanthropy events provide members with opportunities to volunteer with local organizations. Several club members are also Sports Medicine Aides working with D1 sports here at Virginia Tech.

286739.name: Virginia Tech Sustainability (Dining Services)
286739.summary: Virginia Tech Sustainable Dining is a department within Virginia Tech Dining Services. We're proud to help lead the campus in sustainability efforts.
286739.description_html:
What is Virginia Tech Sustainable Dining?

Virginia Tech Sustainable Dining is a sector of Dining Services. We work to actively support the Climate Action Commitment tenets for the university. We are also committed to achieving our internal sustainability objectives within Dining Services. Our mission is to educate students, staff, and faculty about sustainability through outreach. We continue to focus on strategic goals such as: increasing our local and sustainable purchasing, introducing more compostables to our dining centers, ensuring proper waste management with our staff, and much more!

How are we supporting sustainability efforts on campus?

  • Dining Services sources local and sustainable products in our dining centers and uses a “reusable to-go” program to reduce waste.
  • Homefield Farm, a collaboration with Dining Services and the College of Agriculture and Life Sciences, remains one of our sources for campus-grown produce. The twelve-acre educational farm grows fruits, vegetables and herbs for Virginia Tech Dining Services!  
  • We have made, and continue to make, numerous packaging transitions from single-use plastics to compostable products.
  • We maintain three waste streams to ensure proper sorting in our back of house for compost, recycling and trash.
  • We host several outreach events throughout the academic year to education our campus community on sustainability!

Want to get involved? 

Follow our Homefield Farm & Hokie Dining social medias, for more information about sustainability programming and volunteering opportunities. 

Have more questions?

Email sustainabledining@vt.edu.

69129.name: Virginia Tech Table Tennis Club
69129.summary: The Table Tennis Club at Virginia Tech aims to promote the sport of table tennis for students, faculty and community members of all levels. The club is a place for casual practice as well as advanced training for NCTTA Competitions!
69129.description_html:
The organization aims to promote the sport of Table Tennis at Virginia Tech. We hold club meetings Wednesdays and Fridays from 4-8pm, and also Sundays from 2-6pm. Each meeting is within War Memorial Gym's upper table tennis room on the 3rd floor. Additional information is posted in the discord linked below. 

We also hold try-outs for the A-team, B-team, and C-team annually to compete in the National Collegiate Table Tennis Association (NCTTA) organized competitions and have been very successful in the last few years within the Mid-Atlantic Region, having qualified for the Nationals as well. We conduct internal tournaments for the members of the club from time to time and invite other universities for scrimmage tournaments annually. 

For more information and updates, join our discord server or email our Club Secretary Chi Kang Choo at ckchooadrien@vt.edu

63267.name: Virginia Tech Television
63267.summary: Interested in pursuing a career in broadcasting? Want to build reporting or anchoring experience for your resume? You've come to the right place — Virginia Tech's premier television station.
63267.description_html:
The purpose of VTTV is to serve as a television station run for and by Virginia Tech students. We provide television programming unique to our community that would otherwise not be available. We provide an opportunity for members of the college community to learn all aspects of production and management related to the field of television and broadcast media.

We produce multiple studio shows and packages that cover a vast variety of topics inside the news, entertainment, and sports world. VTTV is looking for hardworking anchors, reporters, actors, producers, videographers, and editors. All majors are welcome. 

Interested in joining? Contact us vttv33@gmail.com 

You can also join our mailing list here - https://linktr.ee/vttv33

69706.name: Virginia Tech Triathlon Club
69706.summary: We provide support for student athletes with a desire to participate in the sport of triathlon. As a member of the Mid Atlantic Collegiate Triathlon Conference, we compete at both the regional and national levels in the fall and spring.
69706.description_html:
Virginia Tech Triathlon is an open community of people who love to swim, bike, and/or run. Our goal is to foster a team of athletes who enjoy racing, training, and being around the sport of triathlon. We encourage all to come out to train and have fun with us. We don't have tryouts or any speed requirements to join, so either find us at Gobblerfest, on Instagram @vt_triathlon, or email us at VirginiaTechTri@gmail.com. We have daily practices led by our student coaches as well as race seasons in the fall and spring. As a part of the Mid-Atlantic Collegiate Triathlon Conference, we compete against other colleges at the regional, conference, and national levels.

 

New members click here!!

76264.name: Virginia Tech University Libraries
76264.summary: Virginia Tech's University Libraries is an essential and pioneering partner in achieving student excellence through student programs. We host our own programs and welcome student events in the libraries by offering support in planning.
76264.description_html:
Virginia Tech's University Libraries is an essential and pioneering partner in achieving excellence in research, teaching, and learning. As authoritative guides and stewards of the intellectual record, the Libraries will promote Virginia Tech’s mission by:

  • Providing expert instruction on accessing, evaluating, and utilizing scholarly and research information to achieve success in research and learning;
  • Collecting, sustaining, and providing access to information resources and services whenever and wherever users need them;
  • Improving technology and media literacy to produce graduates who possess a mastery of conveying knowledge through text, image, and multimedia;
  • Providing expertise and a collaborative spirit to faculty and students to produce, manage, and disseminate scholarship and research information in digital form;
  • Improving the physical and virtual environment to facilitate faculty and student productivity;


Developing a library organization that scans its community environment with insight, plans for and assesses its programs with a commitment to continuous improvement, and fosters collaborative and innovative partnerships

137451.name: Virginia Tech University Scholarships and Financial Aid
137451.summary: Using best practices and research to understand how our students will benefit from the financial aid we administer, we will provide the most effective financial aid processes for VT students so they may focus on being academically successful.

69063.name: Virginia Tech Women's Club Basketball
69063.summary: The Virginia Tech Women's Club Basketball was formed in the fall of 2000. Tryouts are held each year for new team members who want to play basketball at a competitive intercollegiate level.
69063.description_html: The Virginia Tech Women’s Club Basketball was formed in the fall of 2000. The team participates in a variety of tournaments year round. Some teams that we compete against include UVA, UNC, NC State, JMU, and Maryland. The team has been able to compete in Regionals and Nationals the past few years at NIRSA events. This included traveling to UMD and making it to the quarter finals. The team tries to travel two-three times a semester, including a home tournament. Tryouts are held each Fall & Spring semester for new team members who want to play basketball at a competitive intercollegiate level. For more information, please visit our website.

69062.name: Virginia Tech Women's Club Lacrosse
69062.summary: Gives women an opportunity to participate in a non-varsity sport in which they can be part of a team and compete extramurally. It may interest those who want to join a competitive team, but are not looking for the stronger commitments of a varsity team.
69062.description_html:
WHEN DO WE PLAY?

We play in the fall, but our main season is in the spring. The fall season is relaxed in comparison to our spring season. We basically use the fall season to get used to playing with the team again. In the fall, we practice 2-3 days a week, and we participate in a few tournaments. During the spring season, we switch into high gear by practicing 2-3 times a week regularly, and we play games during 4-5 weekends. Practices have run from 6-8, Monday-Thursday but are subject to change. Random conditioning gatherings will occur in the event of inclement weather.

WHO DO WE PLAY?

We are currently a member of the Mid-Atlantic Women's Lacrosse League (MAWLL) which includes University of Virginia, James Madison University, University of North Carolina, Towson University, University of Delaware, Pennsylvania State University, West Chester University, and University of Maryland. We have played in tournaments across the country in destinations such as Miami, New Orleans, Pittsburgh, Denver, Scottsdale, Virginia Beach, and Austin. Traveling to these places gives the team nice bonding experiences, as well as providing the players with a chance to visit some places that they otherwise may not see. We host a home tournament on our fields every year, which is a great opportunity to play in front of our fans with a home field advantage! 

HOW MUCH DOES IT COST?

Each player is required to pay for every semester that she plays; dues can vary between $200-500 depending on that season's team expenditures.

WHO COACHES THE TEAM?

There is no official coach. The team is run by the 6 officers who are voted in the previous year.

WHAT ARE OFFICERS?

We have 6 officers who assume the leadership positions of our club team. Click here to read our constitution.

HOW COMPETITIVE IS THIS CLUB?

In 2024, we placed 11th at the National Championships.

In 2023, we won the Regional Championships, which earned us a 4th place bid to the National Championships. 

In 2022, we were second in our conference and received a bid to the WCLA National Championship held in Austin, Texas. We finished 3rd in the nation.

In 2021, we were able to play one game during the spring season against UT.

In 2019, we were second in our conference and received an automatic qualifier bid to the WCLA National Championship held in Virginia Beach, VA. We finished 7th in the nation.

In 2015, we won our conference and received an automatic qualifier bid to the WCLA National Championship held in Virginia Beach, VA. After reaching the championship game, we ended as #2 in the nation.

In 2009, we won the Women's Division Intercollegiate Associates (WDIA) National Championship in Scottsdale, Arizona, ending the year as #1 in the nation.

For years, we have maintained a reputation of being highly competitive, yet capable of having fun. We have won countless tournaments across the country in Miami, New Orleans, College Park, Clemson, Pittsburgh, and Wilmington. We are looking to keep our competitive edge!

HOW DOES ONE MAKE THE TEAM?

We hold an interest meeting at the beginning of each semester (information posted before each semester begins). Please attend this meeting if you think you would like to play. We hold tryouts each fall and spring where we select players according to their ball skill, knowledge of the game, hustle, desire, attitude, attendance, and intention of commitment. We expect those who make the team to attend EVERY practice and EVERY game. Exceptions are made for class or work, however, we ask that if these are going to majorly conflict during the season, you should try to come out a different season.

WHAT ELSE DOES THE TEAM DO?

We try to create strong team unity by participating in activities off the field. We do fundraisers every semester involving pizza and bake sales, auctions, t-shirt sales and much more. We have socials with other club teams and organizations throughout the campus; a great opportunity to meet new people. We have participated in charity events such as Relay for Life and the Marine Mud Run.

70633.name: Virginia Tech Women's Club Soccer
70633.summary: Providing all female students the opportunity to play competitive soccer
70633.description_html: Virginia Tech Women's Club Soccer provides all female students with the opportunity to play competitive soccer while maintaining an athletic and academic balance.

68924.name: Virginia Tech Women's Club Softball
68924.summary: Virginia Tech Women's Softball Club competes against other schools both regionally and nationally in women's fast-pitch softball. The club is looking for new members who want to be involved. It is open to all players seeking competition and fun.
68924.description_html: Virginia Tech Women's Softball Club competes against other schools both regionally and nationally in women's fast-pitch softball. The club is looking for new members who want to be involved and active. It is open to all players seeking competition and fun. We finished the 2021-2022 season and the 2022-2023 season with winning the World Series and being crowned NCSA National Champions!!! We are looking forward to getting the title back and developing our growing program!

68925.name: Virginia Tech Women's Club Tennis
68925.summary: The purpose of this organization is to provide a relaxed and competitive atmosphere for tennis players looking to continue playing competitively after high school. (Tryouts will be held every Fall and Spring)
68925.description_html: This organization provides a community atmosphere for tennis players to compete at Virginia Tech. Participation requirements involving practices and tournaments are flexible and enable members to play when their schedule allows. Tryouts are held every Fall and Spring. Teams of 10-20 players are sent on tournaments throughout the semesters, and a yearly home tournament is usually hosted.

68678.name: Virginia Tech Women's Club Volleyball
68678.summary: Virginia Tech Women's Club Volleyball consists of two competitive teams, the Maroon (A) team and the Orange (B) team. The club competes year round across the nation under the National Collegiate Volleyball Association.
68678.description_html:
Virginia Tech Women's Club Volleyball is a student organization registered through the Division of Student Affairs and the Department of Recreational Sports at Virginia Tech. We are affiliated with the National Collegiate Volleyball Federation (NCVF) and USA Volleyball (USAV). The purpose of VTWCVB is to promote the sport of volleyball and provide opportunities for women to play in competitive tournaments at the collegiate club level. Membership is open to registered female students of the Virginia Tech community. 

     The club's members are selected through a try-out process at the beginning of each semester. Members who wish to try-out should visit the club website for information on times and locations for try-outs. Players will be selected to participate on either the Maroon or Orange Team.

     Each team will have approximately 10-12 team members to allow for a high level of participation by all team members. Teams practice Monday - Thursday, participate in weightlifting multiple times a week, as well as travel and host our own tournaments.

     All members are dedicated, hardworking and committed to the club. They are asked to make every effort to schedule classes around practice time and tournaments and are held accountable to maintaining a high academic standard.

For more information, please contact us at vtclubvolleyball@gmail.com

We look forward to hearing from you!

 

Follow us on Facebook @VirginiaTechWomen'sClubVolleyball 

Instagram @vtclubvolleyball

Website: https://vtclubvolleyball.weebly.com/

 

FALL 2025:

Tryouts - Sep. 8-11 in the Fieldhouse (510 Beamer Way) 

*cuts will be made each day*

69061.name: Virginia Tech Women's Club Water Polo
69061.summary: The women's club water polo team competes in both the fall and spring semesters. Our official competition season is the Spring, and in the Fall we participate in invitationals to practice and prepare. We compete in the Atlantic division of the CWPA.
69061.description_html:
We travel along the east coast to other schools in our region of the CWPA to compete in weekend tournaments. Our main competitive season is the Spring semester, but we practice and travel year round. We practice on Monday and Wednesday evenings in the McCommas pool.

Please contact our president, Anna Goodman (agoodie03@vt.edu) if you are interested in joining or have any questions! We like for new players to join at the beginning of each semester as the Fall serves as a trial period where we teach basic skills and let potential players decide if this sport and team is a good fit for them. A swimming background is helpful but not mandatory.

70186.name: Virginia Tech Women's Rugby Football Club
70186.summary: "You don't have to be great to start, but you have to start to be great"
70186.description_html:
The Virginia Tech Women’s Rugby Club was founded in 1992. Since its founding, we have made it our mission to represent Virginia Tech and the Hokie nation by engaging in competitive play and community service. We stress leadership, hard work, and team unity, which has allowed up to compete and succeed at the highest level of play possible.

We compete on the national Division I Club level under National Collegiate Rugby. Our 15s and 7s teams both face off against nationally-ranked teams and continue to exceed expectations. We are a dual-season sport without tryouts and welcome athletes of various backgrounds. Off the pitch, we are actively involved in the community, raising money for the ALS Foundation. 

 

Our Mission is...

To promote and teach the sport of rugby, allowing players to reach their highest potential in a positive environment while encouraging discipline, commitment, integrity, and team-building both on and off the pitch.

 

Our Vision is...

To provide a safe learning environment giving each player the opportunity to reach their individual potential. 

 

We strive to ensure that each player will be able to have fun, make new friends, experience the unique culture of rugby, and learn about participating positively in a demanding team sport.

 

2018 - 15s National Championship Runners Up

2018 - 7s National Championship Runners Up

2022 - 15s National Championship Runners Up

 

Email our President or reach out through our Instagram to get on the Listserv/ask any questions!

Avery Peacock -- ppeacockk@vt.edu

Instagram -- @vtwomensrugby

157698.name: Virginia Veterinary Medical Association Student Chapter
157698.summary: We serve as the local branch of the VVMA for vet students. We offer early access to our state level professional community. We aim to serve as liaison between VVMA and the student body and offer various opportunities
157698.description_html:
We are the student chapter of our state professional organization, the Virginia Veterinary Medical Association. We offer a variety of networking opportunities and lectures covering a broad span of topics related to veterinary medicine. Our Purpose is to:

  • To supplement students’ veterinary education by providing avenues for learning about veterinary practice, relevant legislation, economic considerations and other pertinent veterinary topics on a local and state level.
  • To help students build professional relationships and network with Virginia veterinarians. 
  • To further strengthen the relationship between students of the CVM and the VVMA.

305240.name: Virodh
305240.summary: Virodh is a competitive Bollywood fusion dance team that aims to promote culture and passion for dance through high-energy choreography and a mix of various different styles in the hopes of showcasing timeless ideas.
305240.description_html: VT Virodh is a competitive Bollywood fusion dance team founded on the ideals of creativity, inclusivity, and innovation. As a co-ed team, Virodh aims to promote culture and passion for dance through high-energy choreography. With a focus on South Asian dance styles, Virodh incorporates various styles from around the world, including Bhangra, Kuthu, Southie, Bollywood, Hip-Hop, Contemporary, and many more, to showcase a mix of timeless ideas year-round.

374060.name: VMCVM Class of 2026
374060.summary: Exclusively consists of students enrolled in the Virginia-Maryland College of Veterinary Medicine DVM class of 2026.
374060.description_html: This organization is exclusively for the students in the Class of 2026 at the Virginia-Maryland College of Veterinary Medicine. We hold various events that foster community building both within the class and with other veterinary school organizations. We offer support our classmates and act as liasions between students and faculty.

387534.name: VMCVM Class of 2027
387534.summary: We are the Class of 2027 at Virginia-Maryland College of Veterinary Medicine
387534.description_html: The Class of 2027 at Virginia-Maryland College of Veterinary Medicine purpose is to grow together and unite over our passion for veterinary medicine while giving back to the community through fundraising and service.

408596.name: VMCVM Class of 2028
408596.summary: This organization is exclusively for students in the Class of 2028 at Virginia-Maryland College of Veterinary Medicine. Our mission is to support and encourage one another as we pursue our passion for making a difference in veterinary medicine.
408596.description_html: VMCVM Class of 2028 is an organization comprised of Class of 2028 veterinary students. Not only are we seeking to leave a lasting impact in veterinary medicine, but we are also dedicated to building community, uplifting one another, and bridging the gap between faculty and staff and the student body. We plan on upholding these goals by being an example and getting involved.

235133.name: VMCVM Veterinary Animal Behavior Club
235133.summary: Our mission is to enable additional educational opportunities for veterinary students to learn about animal behavior through guest speakers, wet labs, etc.
235133.description_html: This club enables additional educational opportunities for students to learn about animal behavior through guest speakers, externship opportunities, group trips, and hands on training activities. An understanding of behavior is helpful to veterinarians regardless of whether they practice small, large, mixed, wildlife, or exotic medicine. Behavior knowledge can help make treatments smoother, more successful, and less scary for patients. Clients will also approach vets with behavior questions, so this club hopes to support a foundation of knowledge that graduates can use in the future.

104909.name: Volunteers Around the World (Dental)
104909.summary: VAW Global Health Alliances sends students abroad to South and Central America during winter/summer breaks to assist in operating a free Dental Clinic. For 14 days, students will experience cultural immersion while giving back to communities in need.
104909.description_html:
VAW Global Health Alliances develops community health systems while providing interns the opportunity to work alongside experienced local healthcare professionals. VAW Global Dental Interns work closely with community partners to implement dental clinics across low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). In the Dental Outreach program, interns learn about healthcare in a global context. Through shadowing local dentists, interns will also learn about dental procedures, treatment courses, clinic operations, and disinfection and sanitation techniques.

Interns will prepare for their trip throughout the year by attending team training sessions, participating in local community service projects, and developing team building activities, led by their Team Leader or Faculty Team Leader. Interns are required to attend trainings and workshops prior to their trip, so that they are well prepared upon arrival in country.

This is an intensive internship — valuable to future dentists, dental hygienists, dental assistants, as well as other future healthcare providers, global practitioners, and anyone interested in gaining skills in public health while supporting healthcare systems around the world.

While on-site, interns will be required to attend several orientations and workshops focused on professional development and cultural sensitivity, which will reinforce the trainings they did leading up to their trip. Additionally, interns will be required to demonstrate proficiency in clinical skills, such as measuring blood pressure, biosecurity and biosafety measures, and other skills — approved by a local healthcare provider — before being allowed to assist in those stations during clinics.

Throughout their time in-country, and especially while in clinic, it is of utmost importance that interns portray health care realities and burden of disease accurately, show professionalism, and respect patients privacy and integrity at all times. During clinics, interns will be placed each day in one of following stations:

Intake

Interns will greet patients as they come into clinic, collect their personal and medical history, and record their current symptoms. They will work with local community leaders, VAW Global staff, and, in some countries, translators. They will record all of the information for the dentist’s review.

Vitals

Interns will measure patients’ vital signs, including blood pressure, under the direct supervision of a locally licensed nurse, physician, or other local healthcare provider. Interns must have tested out of training in order to participate in this station.

Consultation

Interns will have the opportunity to learn about dental procedures and treatment courses by shadowing and assisting locally licensed dentists. If the patient allows, interns will have the opportunity to shadow the consultation and listen as the dentist meets with the patient, does an oral exam, completes the procedures, prescribes treatment (if necessary), and gives general advice; interns will have the opportunity to assist the dentist during the procedure by procuring and passing instruments, among other tasks. This station really provides interns who are engaged and interested with an incredible opportunity to learn healthcare in a global context.

Sterilization and Tray Preparation

Interns will apply cold and hot sterilization techniques for the instruments utilized in consultation. Interns will learn about different instruments, their names, and their usages; they will apply this knowledge to prepare the instrument trays for consultation for an array of procedures. Interns must have passed through the VAW Global Biosafety Protocol Training and Exam prior to participating in this station.

Professional Development Activity

On the two week trip, interns may have the opportunity to participate in an impressions and tooth waxing workshop, which provides an opportunity to learn about the morphology of teeth and develop hand skills.

Cross-Cultural Education Day

Cultural Exchange Day is an opportunity to share the richness of North American culture with children while engaging them in fun, interactive activities.

In-Country Schedule

VAW Global Dental Outreach offers two trip lengths: two weeks (15 days) or one week (7 days). On the two week trip, there will be six clinic days; on the one week trip, there will be three clinic days. Each country varies slightly in how the schedule is arranged and what opportunities are available.

All interns are responsible for covering their program fees, medication and supply fund fee, plane tickets, spending money, and any additional expenses.

VAW Global Health Alliances constantly strives to provide the best quality patient care for our communities and the best professional development opportunities for our interns. We follow the guidelines outlined by leading organizations, such as the American Dental Education Association (ADEA). Please feel free to read through the guidelines ADEA has established for pre-dental students here or visit their website directly here.

74715.name: VPI Cave Club, Student Grotto of the National Speleological Society
74715.summary: The purpose of this club shall be to promote interest in and to advance the science of speleology; to promote conservation of caves and safety in their exploration; and to encourage fellowship among those interested in caving.
74715.description_html:
Our weekly meeting is every Friday, starting at 7:00 PM in Smyth 146 while school is in session (including the Friday of Gobblerfest). At meetings, we have announcements, programs, old/new business, trip reports, and planned trips for the upcoming weekend. So come on out and let's do some caving!

As a reminder, Gobblerconnect is not set up to communicate with folks trying to join. So please email our Vice President at vp@vpicaveclub.org to join our listserv, discord, and hear about caving opportunities!

75806.name: VT Engage: The Center for Leadership and Service Learning
75806.summary: Join us to #ExperienceUtProsim. VT Engage is Virginia Tech's center for service-learning, leadership education, & civic engagement.
75806.description_html:
At VT Engage: The Center for Leadership and Service Learning, our vision is to equip civic leaders to create a more just world. We facilitate leadership, service learning, and civic engagement experiences that advance community priorities, contribute to student development, and embody Ut Prosim (That I May Serve.)
 
Whether you’re new to service, want to engage more deeply with your community, are interested in developing your leadership skills, or learn more about an issue you’re passionate about, we have something for you. All students are welcome to sign up for any experience. To learn more, visit engage.vt.edu or find us at 417 Clay St SW, Blacksburg, VA 24061 – up the path by the tennis courts.

64629.name: VT Student Conduct
64629.summary: Student Conduct at Virginia Tech engages students in intentional conversations and activities that promote deep, reflective learning to foster and strengthen individual and collective values of personal growth, community commitment, and civility.
64629.description_html:
The University Student Conduct System affects and applies to all students who have accepted an offer of admission as an undergraduate, graduate, or professional student and who has not yet graduated or officially transferred to another institution, and to student organizations officially listed with Student Engagement and Campus Life (SECL). Its major purpose is to help create a fair, just, and disciplined university community.

As a team, we approach our work through five core values. We do this in the spirit of living the expressed values of our department, university, and higher education community. We strive to balance the needs and concerns of individuals involved in and connected to our process, as well as those of the larger community. Read more about our work and the five core values on our website.

414726.name: VT-VTC Premed Mentorship Program
414726.summary: The VTCSOM Pre-Medical Mentorship Program connects medical students with aspiring pre-med students to guide them through the journey to medical school.
414726.description_html: The VTCSOM Pre-Medical Mentorship Program fosters connections between medical students and aspiring pre-med students at Virginia Tech and Roanoke College, offering guidance on the admissions process, MCAT, and more. The program strengthens relationships and increases VTCSOM visibility.

414688.name: VTC Anesthesiology Interest Group
414688.summary: The Virginia Tech Carilion School of Medicine's Anesthesiology Interest Group aims to promote education, awareness, and engagement in the field of anesthesiology, fostering a community for medical students interested in the specialty.
414688.description_html: The Virginia Tech Carilion School of Medicine's Anesthesiology Interest Group is dedicated to introducing and educating medical students about the field of anesthesiology, where students have opportunities to learn clinical skills, explore career paths in anesthesiology, and build a supportive network with practicing anesthesiologists in the Roanoke area.

414689.name: VTC Community Partners
414689.summary: The purpose of this club is to engage with Roanoke community members with a broad spectrum of abilities. We will interact with current organizations and the Southwest Virginia community to create relationships through recreational/social/athletic events.
414689.description_html: The purpose of this club is to engage with Roanoke community members with a broad spectrum of abilities. We will interact with current organizations and the Southwest Virginia community to create relationships through recreational, social, and athletic events.

414691.name: VTC Personal Finance Club
414691.summary: The Personal Finance Club at VTCSOM is dedicated to empowering future physicians with the knowledge and skills to confidently navigate personal finance.
414691.description_html: Our goal is to provide students with education on essential financial topics such as budgeting, managing loans, investing in stocks and bonds, and building long-term financial wellness. By fostering financial literacy, we aim to equip members with tools to make informed decisions, reduce stress, and achieve financial independence throughout their careers.

414716.name: VTC Psychiatry Student Interest Group
414716.summary: We are medical students interested in topics in psychiatry, mental health, and the profession of psychiatry.
414716.description_html: Our organization's purpose is to host educational lectures on mental health and offer professional guidance and mentoring for students interested in psychiatry.

414718.name: VTC Students for a National Health Program
414718.summary: VTC Students for a National Health Program is VTC's chapter of the national Students for a National Health Program organization.
414718.description_html: We fight for single payer healthcare through educational and legislative activism. We also engage with matters of health and labor equity, such as class and racial disparities in healthcare outcomes, unionizing resident and attending physicians.

294082.name: VTCC Black Cadet Organization
294082.summary: Serve as a formal support group for Black First-Year Cadets primarily, but also Upperclassmen. Be a space for Black First-Year cadets to interact with upperclassmen cadets and receive advice on: Academics Fitness Corps lifestyle/interactions
294082.description_html: The organization was founded in the spring of 2019 to bring together Black cadets. The Black Cadet Organization (BCO) has evolved into an organization that provides assistance to any cadet who feels in the minority.

420477.name: VTCC HERO
420477.summary: VTCC HERO (Helping Educate Regarding Orientation) is the LGBTQ+ organization in the Virginia Tech Corps of Cadets.
420477.description_html: VTCC HERO (Helping Educate Regarding Orientation) is the LGBTQ+ organization in the Virginia Tech Corps of Cadets. Our vision is to make space for communities to inform the public of topics important to them.

414719.name: VTCSOM Chapter - American Association of Neurological Surgeons
414719.summary: We provide opportunities for medical students to learn more about neurosurgery.
414719.description_html: We provide medical students opportunities to learn more about neurosurgery through networking with current physicians, didactic lectures, panels, SIM center events, cadaver labs, journal clubs, and grand rounds.

414720.name: VTCSOM Chapter - Medical Society of Virginia / American Medical Association
414720.summary: Leads advocacy to promote the science and art of medicine and the betterment of public health. Join the AMA/MSV Club to join professional networks, get involved in issues that matter to you, and train as an effective advocate!
414720.description_html: American Medical Association (AMA) is the largest medical organization in the nation that supports us as medical students and protects our future as physicians. The Medical Society of Virginia (MSV) is your professional association that serves as the voice for more than 30,000 physicians, residents, medical students, PAs, and PA students in all regions of the Commonwealth.

414722.name: VTCSOM Chapter of the Medical Student Pride Alliance
414722.summary: The official VTCSOM chapter of the national Medical Student Pride Alliance.
414722.description_html: MSPA aims to empower sexual & gender minority medical students and allies, increase the number of physicians trained in LGBTQ-inclusive healthcare, and address the unique needs of queer communities through research, advocacy, education, and service.

339937.name: VTCSOM Engage
339937.summary: VTCSOM Engage cultivates relationships with local organizations and community leaders to provide our medical students with longitudinal opportunities for critical service learning and meaningful civic engagement.

414724.name: VTCSOM Medical Spanish Club
414724.summary: The Medical Spanish Club serves to improve student language skills and increase awareness of Hispanic needs within healthcare.
414724.description_html: The Medical Spanish Club at VTCSOM aims to provide an environment where students at any level of Spanish language proficiency can come to improve and practice their Spanish vocabulary and grammar in a medical context, gain unique insights into Latin American culture, and connect students with volunteering and service opportunities for the Hispanic community in Roanoke.

414725.name: VTCSOM Medical Students for Choice
414725.summary: To support future abortion care providers and advocate for reproductive justice globally.
414725.description_html: We believe that all people should have access to health services that allow them to lead safe, healthy lives including all aspects of sexual and reproductive health consistent with their own personal and cultural values.

414659.name: VTCSOM Outdoors Club
414659.summary: We promote fitness and outdoor activities for medical students!
414659.description_html: Plan and organize hikes, runs, and other group activities to promote fitness and spending time in the outdoors!

415421.name: VTDITC: Hip Hop Studies
415421.summary: VTDITC: Hip Hop Studies at Virginia Tech is a practitioner-focused, student-driven, culturally responsive community engagement program that prioritizes experiential learning.
415421.description_html: VTDITC: Hip Hop Studies at Virginia Tech has fostered community and scholarship via Hip Hop Culture since 2016.

68670.name: vtONE
68670.summary: To promote unity in the body of Christ at Virginia Tech and empower each ministry by facilitating inter-ministry prayer, worship, and outreach for the advancement of the Kingdom of God.
68670.description_html:
Purpose:

John 17:21

“that they may all be one, just as you, Father, are in me, and I in you, that they also may be in us, so that the world may believe that you have sent me.”

Mission:

To promote unity in the body of Christ at Virginia Tech and empower each campus ministry by facilitating inter-ministry prayer, worship, and outreach for the advancement of the Kingdom of God.

Vision:

To see revival, through unity in Jesus Christ, at Virginia Tech and the New River Valley realized.

84076.name: VTOnline
84076.summary: OFFICIAL home of Virginia Tech courses online, and via video conferencing. Virginia Tech, Invent the Future ®

70385.name: W.B. Alwood Entomological Society
70385.summary: This organization is made up of the graduate students in the Department of Entomology at Virginia Tech. We work together to promote our department and the study of insects within the university and the community.
70385.description_html: This society recruits students who are interested in insects and other arthropods. We focus on outreach events that involve teaching the community more about the importance of insects and other arthropods, as well as extension efforts teaching locals how to control pests in habitats ranging from small gardens, to large farms, and even urban pest management. This organization mostly contains graduate students studying entomology, but can extend to any university affiliate interested in the subject.

222378.name: Wahala Dance Team at Virginia Tech
222378.summary: We the dancers of Wahala are deeply rooted in our African cultures, traditions, and heritage here at Virginia Tech. We strive to educate the community about African culture through dance.
222378.description_html: We the dancers of Wahala are deeply rooted in our African cultures, traditions, and heritage here at Virginia Tech. We strive to educate the Virginia Tech community about African culture through dance. Our modern and traditional dances tell the stories of Africans' harsh past as well as our fun and lively culture. One of our main goals is to reach out to the African community in the Blacksburg area through social events and service. We wish to bring together people with these passions to form a family.

69919.name: Warhammer 40k Club
69919.summary: We are a club of people that love playing and hobby around Warhammer. We are a community here to share the hobby to all people. Discord: https://discord.gg/RVpUVx592z
69919.description_html: We are a community and organized club of Warhammer enthusiasts that welcome all people. New or seasoned hobbyists are welcome to join us and start or grow their hobby. We would love to have you join us and see all that Warhammer has to offer with this connected community. Message Jackson or Daniel about joining the discord.

145481.name: We Suck at Art Club
145481.summary: We are a no-pressure art club created for anyone of any skill-level to find stress relief, socialize and offer a creative outlet for maintaining mental health.
145481.description_html:
We are a no pressure art club designed for people of all skill levels to join. We recognize the way art and creativity are necessary for maintaining mental health by focusing on stress-relief and creative outlet through unique mediums, such as photography, drawing, coloring, and all mediums of visual art. Members are encouraged to introduce new forms of art to the club, curate their own club experience and create something they are proud of every week.

Spring 2025 club meetings take place on Thursdays from 6:30pm-8:30pm, in Williams Hall 134.

The latest details regarding WSAC meetings and special events can be found on our Instagram (@wesuckatartvt) and Discord (https://discord.gg/vV4yyvTBvR)

62604.name: Wesley Foundation at Virginia Tech
62604.summary: We are a United Methodist Campus Ministry at Virginia Tech focused on spreading the love of God through authentic mission, worship, discipleship, and fellowship. We desire to invite and equip students to explore, engage, and embody an active faith in God
62604.description_html:
We are a United Methodist Campus Ministry at Virginia Tech focused on spreading the love of God through authentic mission, worship, discipleship, and fellowship. We desire to invite and equip students to explore, engage,and embody an active faith in God.

This year we will be growing closer together as people and in faith together through events in our building. We will continue to be an open and affirming community to all.

349810.name: West Eggleston Hall Community
349810.summary: Residents and Friends of West Egg

349688.name: Whitehurst Hall Community
349688.summary: Residents and friends of Whitehurst Hall
349688.description_html: Whitehurst is a high-energy all-male community featuring a diverse range of identities. While smaller than some others, Whitehurst has a very tight knit community. It overlooks the President’s Quad which is a great place to hang out and meet new people. With newly remodeled bathrooms and kitchen, Whitehurst is a great place to start your college experience.

414727.name: Wilderness Medicine Interest Group
414727.summary: The VTC WMIG trains future physicians in wilderness medicine through hands-on skills, outdoor adventures, and emergency care in remote settings.
414727.description_html: Provide medical students with hands-on training in austere medical skills and prehospital care through workshops, outdoor excursions, and mentorship from experienced faculty to foster a passion for adventure and resourceful problem-solving.

147037.name: Wind Turbine Team at Virginia Tech
147037.summary: The Wind Turbine Team at Virginia Tech works to design and build a functioning, small-scale wind turbine. The goal of this organization is to successfully compete in the Collegiate Wind Competition.
147037.description_html:
The Wind Turbine Team at Virginia Tech works to design and build a functioning, small-scale wind turbine and develop a mock Wind Farm. The goal of this organization is to provide its members with the opportunity to acquire skills in wind energy and compete in the Department of Energy sponsored Collegiate Wind Competition. This competition requires the team to design and build a prototype wind turbine, advance the reputation for wind energy within our community, and create an economically feasible wind farm. Our organization is open to all majors with an emphasis placed on connecting with students who have an interest in Engineering, Business, and Sustainability majors. Our team facilitates hands-on experience and leadership skills.

 

We are design operating out of the AEDL maker space.

69194.name: Wishmakers at Virginia Tech
69194.summary: Giving hope, strength, and joy to children with life-threatening medical conditions.
69194.description_html: Wishmakers at VT is a way to connect with students of all ages and majors to support a cause near and dear to our hearts - the Make-A-Wish Foundation. The Make-a-Wish foundation strives to grant the wish of every child diagnosed with a critical illness. In the U.S. and its territories, a wish is granted every 34 minutes. A wish can be that spark that helps these children believe that anything is possible and gives them the strength to fight harder against the illness that they are facing. This club's main goal throughout the year is to raise money by hosting and attending fun events on and off campus. We also do community outreach with children's hospitals in the community and the Give Kids the World Village at Disney World!

400650.name: Women in Architecture and Design at Virginia Tech
400650.summary: Empowering women to create and innovate, while building a supportive community that fosters lasting connections.
400650.description_html: The Women in Architecture and Design (WiAD) club at Virginia Tech is a community dedicated to supporting and empowering women in the fields of architecture and design. Through workshops, lectures, and networking events, WiAD promotes professional development, celebrates diverse voices, and addresses challenges faced by women in these disciplines.

365359.name: Women in Cybersecurity at Virginia Tech
365359.summary: Our Mission is to help build a strong gender-diverse cybersecurity workforce by facilitating recruitment, retention and advancement for women in the field.
365359.description_html: At WiCyS, a global community of women, allies and advocates, we are dedicated to bringing talented women together to celebrate and foster their passion and drive for cybersecurity. We unite local communities of aspiring and thriving women cybersecurity professionals across the world to collaborate, share their knowledge, network and mentor. We create opportunities through professional development programs, conferences, career fairs, and more.

420478.name: Women in Data Science At Virginia Tech
420478.summary: Women in Data Science at Virginia Tech (WiDS@VT) aims to inspire individuals to explore the interdisciplinary applications of data science & empowers women to reach their full potential as data science leaders through learning, mentorship, and community.

387510.name: Women in Electrical and Computer Engineering at Virginia Tech
387510.summary: WECE is an inclusive organization with the goal of aiding our members, primarily composed of women in the electrical and computer engineering field, in social and professional advancement.
387510.description_html: WECE is an organization that strives to create a comforting and inclusive environment for women and other gender minorities in the electrical and computer engineering majors/fields. We are passionate about giving our members the tools to succeed in this major and beyond college. WECE is open to anyone who may be interested, regardless of gender or major!

344842.name: Women in Industrial and Systems Engineering
344842.summary: Leveraging women’s collective knowledge, wisdom, and fellowship as the keystones for cultivating ethical, comprehensive, and robust industrial and system engineers in human factors, ergonomics, operations research, management systems, and manufacturing.
344842.description_html:
WISE will provide formal and informal camaraderie, mentoring, and knowledge acquisition opportunities for all levels and specialties within the industrial and systems engineering profession. Some of these opportunities are centered around issues uniquely experienced by women engineers. However, all ISE students are welcome to join as we will have other foci like finding job postings, resume building, etc.

The ISE umbrella encapsulates the specialties of human factors, ergonomics, operations research, management systems, and manufacturing systems. At the undergraduate level, industrial and systems engineers learn elements from each specialty and employ them all in the workforce. At the graduate level, these specialties diverge and have their own student groups. Many groups at the graduate level (see HFES, INFORMS, etc.) focus on specific specialty areas and not the full breadth of ISE. It is our belief that a mixed grad/undergrad group maintaining the connections between specialties further ensures well-rounded engineers and better mentorship for curious undergraduate students considering each specialty. The hope is also to build a group of WISE-alum with whom current students can connect with and seek mentorship.

Follow us on Instagram and LinkedIn!

70703.name: Women in Mining
70703.summary: To support women in the mining industry, as well as educate the community about mining
70703.description_html: We meet as a group to do fun activities, learn about mining, share our experiences and support each other.

387551.name: Women of Economics Club at Virginia Tech
387551.summary: The club’s mission is to foster a supportive community where economics students can connect, collaborate, and encourage one another in their academic and professional growth.
387551.description_html: Our club meets monthly to provide a supportive environment where students can study, learn, and grow to their fullest potential. We welcome everyone who shares our passion for economics and our commitment to supporting one another.

71285.name: Women Transportation Seminar Central Virginia Chapter
71285.summary: WTS is an international organization dedicated to the advancement of women in the transportation industry with nearly 5000 members.
71285.description_html: WTS is a global organization committed to advancing women’s careers in transportation. By offering professional development programs, networking events, and student scholarships—along with direct access to industry and government leaders—WTS helps women gain both opportunities and recognition. In doing so, it transforms the glass ceiling into a gateway for career growth.

105778.name: Women's Center
105778.summary: Our mission is to promote a Virginia Tech community that is safe, equitable, and supportive for women and that celebrates their experiences, achievements, and diversity.
105778.description_html:
We are a confidential service that provides prevention education and confidential advocacy for faculty, students and staff of all* genders. 

 

Accessibility Statement:

The Women's Center is not ADA Certified*

The Women's Center has fluorescent lighting in the reception area, kitchen, main floor bathroom, and lower level. Many office spaces solely use soft lamp lighting instead of the overhead lighting installed. The Women's Center is scent-free, however we cannot guarantee scents worn by people who enter into the space. 

Parking

The Women's Center has limited free parking of 10 spaces and one handicap space. Women's Center staff also use this lot. Therefore, parking is limited during regular office hours.

Main Level

The front Washington St. entrance of the Women's Center has a wheelchair ramp, while the side entrance has two steps. There are two bathrooms on the main level. One has two steps leading to it, while the other is wheelchair accessible. *Exact measurements coming soon. There is one advocacy support person available on this level.

Upstairs Level

This level has one bathroom and four offices. Two advocacy offices are upstairs.

Lower Level

The lower level of the Women's Center is wheelchair accessible, however, we are not ADA certified. The lower level is an open space with an accessible single restroom on the same floor. *Exact measurements coming soon. Overhead lights are fluorescent, however there are options for accommodating sensory needs around fluorescent lighting. 

More Accessibility Details Coming Soon*

327256.name: Women's Ice Hockey Team at Virginia Tech
327256.summary: An inclusive organization that strives to make hockey a welcoming community and aims to diversify and grow women's ice hockey.
327256.description_html:
2021 Women's Atlantic Coast Collegiate Hockey League (WACCHL) Champions. Most practices and games are held at The Bergland Center in Roanoke, VA, while additional conditioning takes place on campus. 

We are committed to creating strong bonds between teammates and our community. Together, we strive to be competitive in our league, pushing ourselves and each other to achieve our fullest potential. Contact us if you're interested in playing ice hockey with a supportive and hard-working group!

Instagram: @vtwhockey

Website: https://www.vtwhockey.com/

63159.name: Women's Ultimate Frisbee Club
63159.summary: As a team, we try to teach and promote the sport of Ultimate Frisbee on campus, while traveling to 3 to 4 weekend tournaments throughout the year.
63159.description_html: We are a group of awesome people who meet three times a week to play ultimate frisbee on the intramural and lacrosse fields. We welcome all levels and years; we love new faces! We travel 3-4 times a semester to tournaments in varying states on the east coast. Overall, our goals are to promote personal development and skill improvement while having fun and spreading the game of ultimate frisbee. We are all about supporting strong active women in sports by fostering relationships and teamwork!

69715.name: Wood Enterprise Institute
69715.summary: Organization to practice concept to market sustainable business applications in the design and innovation of wood products.
69715.description_html: The Wood Enterprise Institute (WEI) is a student-run entrepreneurial venture managed by students with the support of the Department of Sustainable Biomaterials and the College of Natural Resources and Environment at Virginia Tech. The goal of WEI is to successfully introduce a wood product from concept to market, through new product development, product marketing, product manufacturing, and sales. Through this experience, students learn how to organize, manage, and improve a business in the most sustainable manner.

72713.name: Wrestling Club at Virginia Tech
72713.summary: We're a group of friends built around wrestling & an ABOUT IT mentality.  Whether you're a veteran wrestler, you're just starting, or never want to touch a mat, we've got room for you.  Come out to practices, competitions and club trips.
72713.description_html:
Wrestling Club is a group of friends built around an exciting sport & ABOUT IT mentality!

 

For veteran wrestlers, Wrestling Club offers the opportunity to continue high-level national competition in the NCWA. For beginners, getting the opportunity to learn about the sport from veteran coaches helps keep fit.  Even for those who have no interest in stepping on a mat, wrestling club social events, road trips, BBQ's, and more can complete their college experience.

 

We practices 5 times per week.  We have structured practices Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, and open mats on Friday.  Practices are totally optional and dues are cheap!  Reach out for more information on getting started!

 

We are centered around competition.  As 2023 and 2024 MAC Conference Champions, our competitive lineup consists of multiple-time state champions, former DI wrestlers, and NCWA Academic All-Americans.  We compete six times in the regular season, once in the Mid Atlantic Conference, and at NCWA nationals every year.  From Liberty University to Puerto Rico, we've dominated the mat.

 

However, much of the liveliness in Club Wrestling comes outside of our own competition.  Life-changing road trips usually center around watching DI Wrestling at other colleges.  We routinely travel far across the country to catch every match.  From UVA & NCSU, to Ohio State, UNC, and Duke, we find ways to have the time of our lives supporting our fellow Hokies and enjoying other college campuses for a weekend at a time.

 

Reach out for more info!

408597.name: Wushu-Kung Fu Club
408597.summary: The Virginia Tech Wushu & Kung Fu Club promotes Chinese martial arts through training, workshops, and cultural events. We foster discipline, self-defense, and artistic expression while building community, leadership, and diversity.
408597.description_html: The Virginia Tech Wushu & Kung Fu Club seeks to promote the practice, appreciation, and cultural awareness of traditional and contemporary Chinese martial arts among the university community. We seek to create an open environment for students to learn and practice Wushu and Kung Fu with an emphasis on physical conditioning, discipline, self-defense, and artistic expression. This club will hold regular practice sessions, workshops, and provide students with the opportunity to engage in performances, competitions, and cultural events. By doing so, we hope to create a sense of community, create leadership roles, and enhance diversity by exposing people to the rich history and philosophy that these martial arts have to offer. By combining physical training with cultural education, the Virginia Tech Wushu & Kung Fu Club will provide students with an opportunity for self-development while echoing the university's dedication to all-around development and cultural involvement.

62829.name: WUVT, Division of EMCVT, Inc
62829.summary: WUVT's is Virginia Tech's student-run radio station! WUVT's mission is to promote education, understanding, and diversity of music while serving the community as an independent, non-profit, non-commercial, student-run radio station.
62829.description_html:
WUVT is Virginia Tech's student-run radio station!


WUVT's mission is to promote education, understanding, and diversity of music while serving the community as an independent, not-for-profit, student-run radio station. Our goal to provide diverse, eclectic, and educational programming makes us a truly unique organization. The vast majority of music played on WUVT cannot be heard anywhere else on your radio dial.


WUVT has a large team of student DJs, artists, writers, and musicians. We host a semesterly organizational information session (the orgy) where we share information on each of our staffs, information on how to train to be an on-air FM DJ, and other updates on cool projects and events we have planned. DJ training accepts applications at the beginning of each semester.

WUVT also hosts frequent music-related events on and around campus, so keep an eye out for our remote radio booth, or an ear out for our semesterly open mics -- Green Eggs & Jam! Check out our website to catch a live stream of our broadcast, see archived DJ playlists, or to find staffhead information so you can contact the right people to get involved.

81730.name: XYZ Gallery Student Art Association
81730.summary: XYZ Art Gallery is a great place to learn about the inner workings of a gallery. We plan art exhibits, music events, poetry readings and other community events! Come to a meeting to learn how you can be a part of our organization!
81730.description_html:
XYZ Art Gallery is a great place for artists and art lovers to work together to promote the arts in Blacksburg! We plan show openings, hang art work, and plan a variety of other events. We have an annual Silent Auction in December.

We are always looking for people to help out in the gallery! Jobs can always be created and ideas/advice are always accepted. You do not have to be an art major to join! We have had science majors, engineers, architecture students, and english students work for the gallery! 

XYZ is a great place to gain experience in curating, advertising, graphic design, communications, and working in an art gallery! It is a great resume booster, not to mention we have a great time! 

Follow our Instagram and like our Facebook page for updates on meeting times and events! If you are interested in joining, send us an e-mail or stop by a meeting!

70234.name: YMCA at Virginia Tech
70234.summary: We are VT's second oldest student organization! Our mission is leadership development, healthy living, and social responsibility. As an international organization, we offer a unique opportunity to serve in and learn about many communities.
70234.description_html:
The YMCA Student Programs consists of Virginia Tech student volunteers that serve in the New River Valley, across the USA, and internationally. We encourage students to join us in volunteerism. You can volunteer on an hourly or weekly basis.  If you would like to run your own service program, apply to be one of our Program Leaders or contact us about a program that you would like to start! If you are interested in more general leadership opportunities, apply for one of our executive council positions!

The YMCA at Virginia Tech has several student-led programs that work to support and enrich the community. These programs include: 

    • After-School  
    • Montgomery county is currently a “child-care desert.” The YMCA provides crucial after-school care to children attending Blacksburg Middle School. Program leaders work to enrich the lives of these students and offer mentorship to them outside the school day. 
    • Event Planning 
    • The YMCA offers many events throughout the year to build ties throughout the community. These events work to connect all walks of life in the community, the town, the county, and public schools. 
    • Healthy Kids Day 
    • Healthy Kids Day is the Y’s national initiative to improve the health and well-being of kids and families. For over 30 years, YMCAs and their communities hosted free community events aimed to inspire kids and families to keep their minds and bodies active throughout the summer months and beyond. 
    • Joining Generations 
    • Volunteers get paired with a senior based on their mutual interests. They spend time together with seniors at English Meadows, Commonwealth Senior Living, and Heritage Hall by socializing, sharing craft activities, exchanging stories, and celebrating life. Joining Generations is about building relationships your “adopted grandparent” just might become one of your closest friends! 
    • Literacy Program 
    • The YMCA provides English Second Language classes to families of the Blacksburg community. In order to remove barriers to English Education, childcare is provided while parents attend the lessons. Classes take place every Monday, Tuesday, and Thursday, with the assistance of student volunteers. 
    • Meals on Main 
    • Meals on Main is the YMCA’s anti-hunger initiative. This program currently serves children in the community 18 years and younger by providing them with nutritious meals. The program works to connect community members in need with food assistance. 
    • Y-TOSS 
    • The YMCA at Virginia Tech coordinates Y-TOSS, one of the largest sustainability initiatives on campus. Each year, the program collects gently used items from the dorms during the student move-out days. The items are then made available to incoming students during the fall move-in sale at the Lancaster House across from the Virginia Tech campus. All proceeds support YMCA programming. 

The YMCA Student Programs office is conveniently located off of Washington St, by the tennis courts. Email engagement@vtymca.org for more information!

160750.name: Young Democratic Socialists of America
160750.summary: The youth section of Democratic Socialists of America, fighting for economic and social justice at Virginia Tech for the many, not the few.
160750.description_html: We are the youth section of Democratic Socialists of America. Our goal is to work on campaigns at Virginia Tech and within the Blacksburg community to fight for economic justice, democracy, and the rights of the exploited and oppressed.

69270.name: Young Democrats at Virginia Tech
69270.summary: We're the students who keep Blacksburg blue. Official VAYD chapter at Virginia Tech.
69270.description_html:
Fall 2025 meetings: Thursdays from 5-6pm in Lavery Hall, Room 345!

 

The Young Democrats at Virginia Tech is an organization of Tech's brightest students dedicated to electing Democrats and promoting progressive values. We hold meetings every week, alongside events where our members get unique opportunities to work on campaigns, meet political figures, and talk about the issues nearest and dearest to their hearts. We also attend an annual convention where members get the chance to be elected to positions that represent the entire commonwealth and advocate for issues they care about.

 

If you are interested in being a part of the next generation of leaders across Virginia and the nation, join VTYD!

327258.name: Zeta Beta Tau Fraternity
327258.summary: The Delta Xi Chapter of Zeta Beta Tau is a powerhouse of excellence at Virginia Tech. ZBT is for those who want to make the most of their college experience. Our mission; is to foster and develop brotherhood for a lifetime.
327258.description_html: Zeta Beta Tau Fraternity was founded on December 29, 1898, at City College of New York. Founded as a Zionist Organization, it was created for Jewish men who were excluded from joining other men's Fraternities. Since 1954, ZBT has been committed to its policy of non-sectarian brotherhood, and values the diversity of its brothers. ZBT will recruit and initiate men of good character, regardless of religion, race or creed who are accepting of these principles. The mission of Zeta Beta Tau Fraternity (ZBT) is to foster and develop in its brotherhood the tenets of its Credo: Intellectual Awareness, Social Responsibility, Integrity and Brotherly Love, in order to prepare its brothers for positions of leadership and service within their communities. Brothers of Zeta Beta Tau participate in philanthropy & service, athletic events, social events, brotherhood events, leadership conventions, and much more. Our motto is, "Brotherhood for a Lifetime" as we foster relationships not for just four years, but an entire lifetime.

69271.name: Zeta Phi Beta Sorority, Inc.
69271.summary: The UNBEATABLE Upsilon Lambda Chapter of Zeta Phi Beta Sorority, Inc., was chartered at VT on May 22, 1982, by 7 exceptional women. These women strived daily to uphold the principles of the sorority: Scholarship, Service, Sisterhood, and Finer Womanhood
69271.description_html:
Zeta Phi Beta Sorority, Incorporated was founded on January 16, 1920, at Howard University, Washington, D.C. The Klan was active during this period, and the Harlem Renaissance was acknowledged as the first important movement of Black artists and writers in the U.S. This same year the Volstead Act became effective, heralding the start of Prohibition and Tennessee delivered the crucial 36th ratification for the final adoption of the 19th amendment giving women the right to vote. The worst and longest economic recession to hit the U.S. would define the end of the decade-The Great Depression.

Within this environment, five coeds envisioned a sorority that would directly affect positive change, chart a course of action for the 1920s and beyond, raise people’s consciousness, encourage the highest standards of scholastic achievement, and foster a greater sense of unity among its members. These women believed that sorority elitism and socializing overshadowed the real mission of progressive organizations and failed to address fully the societal mores, ills, prejudices, and poverty affecting humanity in general and the black community in particular.

Since its inception, Zeta has continued its steady climb into the national spotlight with programs designed to demonstrate concern for the human condition both nationally and internationally.

The sorority takes pride in its continued participation in transforming communities through volunteer services from members and its auxiliaries. Zeta Phi Beta has chartered hundreds of chapters worldwide and has a membership of 100,000+.

The UNBEATABLE Upsilon Lambda Chapter of Zeta Phi Beta Sorority, Inc., was chartered on the campus of Virginia Tech on May 22, 1982 by seven exceptional women. These women strived daily to uphold the four principles in which the sorority stands for: Scholarship, Service, Sisterhood, and Finer Womanhood.

74663.name: Zeta Psi
74663.summary: The Alpha Pi Chapter of Zeta Psi at Virginia Tech is a Greek organization centralized around our beautiful historic home on East Roanoke Street. We maintain a close knit brotherhood averaging around 40 members and we are consistently striving to improve.
74663.description_html:
The major characteristic which makes fraternities differ from one another is the type of individual involved. In Zeta Psi, we firmly believe in this concept. The Zeta Psi Fraternity of North America was founded in 1847 with the ideals of developing young men into purposeful, free-thinking, community-minded individuals. We are smaller than some of the other fraternities in the Interfraternity Conference (IFC), but we have many great accomplishments under our belts. Zeta Psi became the first truly national fraternity, when we started our chapter at the University of California at Berkley in 1870. We also became the first international fraternity when the chapter at the University of Toronto was started in 1879. Other firsts include the first fraternity at all eight Ivy League schools simultaneously, and the first fraternity on the campuses of Tufts, Cornell, Berkeley, Toronto, McGill, Case Western Reserve, Stanford, Alberta, Calgary, Claremont, and the University of Manitoba. 

We put a strong emphasis on the individual, not only in recruitment and training, but in career development, alumni affiliation, and lifelong participation. We want our brother to feel that he is a stronger individual for his association with us, not simply a member of a group. 

We are often called the "Ivy League Fraternity". As Zeta Psi chapters spread across the North American continent, we did not stray from our original mission. We have approximately 60 active chapters throughout the United States and Canada. Our chapter roll speaks for itself. We maintain our selective group by choice, rather than compromise the integrity of our brotherhood. Zeta Psi has built a reputation for establishing chapters at only the premier academic institutions in the U.S. and Canada. No other fraternity can match this impressive list." 


-Courtesy of the University of Manitoba's Zeta Psi site

69908.name: Zeta Tau Alpha
69908.summary: Zeta Tau Alpha is a women's fraternity that aims to intensify friendship, foster a spirit of love, and build a purer and nobler womanhood in the world. Our philanthropy is Breast Cancer Education and Awareness.
69908.description_html:
The Eta Xi chapter of Zeta Tau Alpha was chartered at Virginia Tech on April 29, 1972. This makes ZTA one of VT’s oldest sororities and Zeta’s 157th link in the national chain of chapters. Virginia Tech’s chapter was founded upon the high ideals of Zeta Tau Alpha and the high standards of Virginia Tech.  Both at the local and national level, the Eta Xi chapter has been recognized for their fulfillment of these ideals and most importantly, for our sisterhood. Every day, Eta Xi’s members encompass the spirit of our organization as they continuously strive for academic, social, and philanthropic excellence.

 

Virginia Tech Zetas take pride in working together to achieve common goals and strive each day to fulfill zeta ideals of sisterhood, achievement, service, and love. ZTA women are multifaceted and are encouraged to lend their talents to many areas of collegiate life, with members being incredibly involved in campus organizations, sports teams, and student councils.  As an organization, ZTA aims to provide ongoing support and encouragement to each sister in her extracurricular activities.

 

Whether members are at Hokie football games, a Panhellenic sponsored event, or simply spending time with friends, the sisterhood intended by our founders is clearly present in everything we do. Zeta Tau Alpha at Virginia Tech values its members, its Panhellenic community, its University, and its future potential.  The sisters of Zeta Tau Alpha look forward to passing along the love, support, and sisterhood of our organization to new members for years to come.

 

Success opens doors; friends open hearts. Whether you are looking for opportunities in leadership, scholastics or service, or if you just want to make new friends that will make you laugh, you will find what you are looking for in Zeta Tau Alpha.

96358.name: Zoo, Exotic Pet, and Wildlife Medicine Club at Virginia Tech
96358.summary: Student club at VMCVM catering to veterinary students interested in zoo, exotic pet, and wildlife veterinary medicine.
96358.description_html:
The Zoo, Exotic Pet, and Wildlife Medicine (ZEW) Club at the Virginia-Maryland College of Veterinary Medicine is dedicated to supporting vet students interested in zoo animal, exotic pet, and wildlife veterinary care. We provide valuable resources, information, and hands-on experiences to enhance their skills in these specialized fields.

The ZEW Club hosts a variety of events, including wet labs, guest speaker presentations, and field trips, all aimed at expanding students' knowledge and passion for working with these species. Additionally, the club manages the Wildlife Ward, offering students hands-on experience treating wildlife brought into the Veterinary Teaching Hospital.

Our organization houses student chapters of the following professional organizations: the Association of Avian Veterinarians, the Association of Reptile and Amphibian Veterinarians, the American Association of Zoo Veterinarians, the American Association of Wildlife Veterinarians, and the World Aquatic Veterinary Medical Association.

Please note that membership is only open to vet students at VMCVM.
